Achieve your biological potential by subbing and watching weekly! \nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCUJgAQ1GqykXO89sfdribfQ?sub_confirmation=1\n\n\ud83d\udcd9 Buy My Book To Enhance Your Health, Energy, And Impact \ud83d\udcd9\nAmazon Link  \u27a1   https://bit.ly/BuffEnoughBook\n_________________________________________________________________\n\nThank you so much for watching :)\nNow get out there and make your positive impact! \n- Floyd Meyer\n\n\nTranscript\nHRV is a measure of your overall cardiovascular health. And by far the most efficient way to increase cardiovascular fitness is through High-Intensity Interval Training. \n\nHigh-Intensity Interval Training or HIIT can give you the stimulus that you need to keep your heart strong, in as little as 10 minutes! When your heart and nervous system are robust you are able to deal with stress no matter where it is coming from. \n\nMany people spend hours on the treadmill, \u201cjogging\u201d, without seeing any real results. It is not to say that exercise like that is bad. Any level of physical activity is better than nothing, but unfortunately for most people, it does not provide the strong stimulus that our bodies need in order to activate the hormetic pathways that will lead to increases in our cardiovascular fitness. \n\nWhy is HIIT so effective then? \n\nBecause it allows you to get a higher intensity than you would be able to achieve with other types of exercise. In other words, you can really push the intensity of the exercise that you are doing because you only do it for 20 seconds to 1 minute at a time. \nThen you recover until you are ready for the next round.\n\nThis sequential strong stimulus will cause your body to respond by growing new blood vessels, raising testosterone, building muscle, and turning on a bunch of health-promoting pathways.  \n \nAs your body adapts to these sequential stressful events you become more resilient and this will be seen in your heart rate variability scores. \n\nWhat this means is that overtime your heart and nervous system will become better at dealing with high stress situations and be better at bringing you back down to baseline during the rest intervals. Which is exactly what it means to have a healthy cardiovascular and nervous system. \n\nYou need to be able to do both. You need to be able to ramp it up when you are in a high pressure situation, and then bring it back down to baseline once the stressful event ends. \n\nThink of HIIT not as an exact workout plan, but as a way of exercising. \n\nYou can add HIIT training to weightlifting, bodyweight exercises, running, walking, biking, or swimming, whatever it is that you like to do. \n\nThis will guarantee you the strong stimulus you need in order to maximize the benefits of exercise. \n\nBut please remember, \u201cThe best form of exercise is the one you will actually do!\u201d\n\nIf you enjoy riding your bike do that. If you like to lift weights by all means keep doing it. Find what you enjoy and stick to it. That is what is going to keep you fit enough to live a long healthy life.\n\nIf you are interested in learning more about HIIT and want me to show you exactly how to implement it today including what apps I use, how long to set the intervals for, plus a bunch of bonus content make sure to sign up for my Free HIIT Masterclass on my website. I\u2019ll be detailing all of the benefits of HIIT and how to get started NOW so you can stop wasting your time and start getting real results. Use Code DLAUER10 on Natural Heaven Low-Carb Pasta: https://eatnaturalheaven.com/products/angel-hair-veggie-noodles-natural-heaven\n\nThis video does contain a paid partnership with a brand that helps to support this channel. The name, \u201coleic acid\u201d comes from the Latin, \u201coleum\u201d meaning \u201coil.\u201d Basically, I\u2019m saying that EVOO is the original gangster (OG) of oils. \n\nOleoylethanolamine (OEA) synthesis: Dietary oleic acid is converted into OAE through the two-step \u201ctransacylation-phosphodiesterase pathway.\u201d First, oleic acid is converted into N-oleoyl-phosphatidylethanolamine (NOPE) by the enzyme NAT, then NOPE is converted into OAE by the enzyme NAPE-PLD. The synthesis of OEA occurs in the small intestine, liver, and within most peripheral tissues. In fact, it\u2019s been suggested that the reason plasma OEA correlates with oleic acid consumption is not because OEA is being produced in the intestines/liver and being transported, but rather than OEA can spill over into the bloodstream after being synthesized from oleic acid by peripheral tissues. \n\nOEA signaling: OEA binds the transcription factor PPAR\u03b1, which causes PPAR\u03b1 to form a heterodimer with RXR that binds to PPAR\u03b1 response elements on DNA and increases the expression of several genes, including those involved in lipid transport, \u03b2-oxidation, lipoprotein uptake, etc. Specifically, PPAR\u03b1 increases the expression of the fat transporter protein CD36 and uncoupling (fat-browning) protein UCP-2 to increase fat burning. OEA also binds the TRPV1 receptor the stimulation of which sends a satiety signal from the gut to the brain via the Vagus nerve. Interestingly, it appears that the cuddle hormone, oxytocin, is important in this mechanism. The Vagus nerve talks to the nucleus of the solitary tract in the hypothalamus, stimulating oxytocin release and inducing satiety. \n\nOEA knockout rats: Rats lacking the enzyme, NAPE-LD, that makes OEA from oleic acid exhibit obesity, insulin resistance, increased cholesterol and triglycerides, increased inflammation, and an impaired fat browning in response to cold.\nProgress in Lipid Research 2017, Review https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28389247 \n\n(For more on OEA, see oleoylethanolamine document, or ask Nick to resend.)\n\nPolyphenols (Oleocanthal & Hydroxytyrosol)\nEVOO contains at least 36 different antioxidant polyphenols. It\u2019s impossible to concisely characterize the benefits of all 36, so we will discuss just two examples: oleocanthal and hydroxytyrosol.\n\nOleocanthal\nInflammation. Oleocanthal inhibits the pro-inflammatory COX enzymes that contribute to a wide manner of inflammatory diseases Nature 2005 https://www.nature.com/articles/437045a \n\nAlzheimer\u2019s: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19631677 \n\nAlzheimer\u2019s: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19549281 \n\nHydroxytyrosol\nHydorxytyrosol is another phenolic compound found at high levels in EVOO. It is among the strongest antioxidants found in nature, with 10-times the antioxidant power of green tea.\n\nRefined olive oils and fake EVOOS contain only about 10% the hydroxytyrosol as found in true EVOO. \n\nHydroxytyrosol concentrations in olives vary by variety. Greek black olives contain 100-340 mg/kg, whereas Greek kalamata olives contain 250-750 mg/kg.\n\nHeart. The European Food & Safety Authority has stated that hydroxytyrosol protects the cardiovascular system and prevents atherosclerosis.\n\nBrain. Hydroxytyrosol protects against Alzheimer\u2019s and Parkinson\u2019s disease by crossing the blood-brain barrier and protecting the brain\u2019s precious fats from oxidation. \n\nCancer. Consumption of 50 \u00b5M\u2013100 \u00b5M hydroxytyrosol, from EVOO or olives, has been shown to inhibit the growth of leukemia, adenocarcinoma, colon cancer, and breast cancer cells. \n\nMedicines 2018 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5874578\n\nNicholas Norwitz - Oxford PhD Researcher and Harvard Med Student: \nhttps://www.dpag.ox.ac.uk/team/nicholas-norwitz", "tags": ["olive oil", "olive oil benefits", "olive oil weight loss", "olive oil fat loss", "olive oil for fat loss", "olive oil for weight loss", "olive oil and fat burning", "benefits of olive oil", "olive oil superfood", "superfoods", "what are superfoods", "which foods are superfoods", "olive oil is a superfood", "superfood olive oil", "olive oil alzheimer's", "olive oil brain", "olive oil heart health", "thomas delauer", "olive oil eyes", "keto", "keto olive oil", "intermittent fasting", "weight loss", "fat loss"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT9M2S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "2631", "dislikeCount": "60", "viewCount": "46624", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "263"}, "id": "SKuMOFzouaE"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2017.04.001"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.im.2017.04.001", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Patrick McLaughlin, MD talks about selecting a Prostate Cancer Treatment - Part I.", "channelId": "UCpNPxVR4gwRICHt1LXHjpow", "channelTitle": "Prostate Cancer Information Group", "publishedAt": "2020-05-28T18:01:23Z", "description": "Title: The Modern Definition of Successful Cancer Treatment: Cure with Quality of Life Approaches to Individualized Patient Advocacy. More info on how to join in here: http://www.ericrscott.com/2019/09/06/tea-science-tuesday/\n\nBibliography:\n\n*IMPORTANT*: Do NOT pay to access any scientific papers linked below! V., Adam, M., Khatami, R., Luhmann, U. F. O., Jung, H. H., Berger, W., et al. (2007). A Genetic Variation in the Adenosine A2A Receptor Gene (ADORA2A) Contributes to Individual Sensitivity to Caffeine Effects on Sleep. Clin. Pharmacol. Ther. 81, 692\u2013698. https://doi.org/10.1038/sj.clpt.6100102\n\nThe authors show that there is genetic variation in a receptor that caffeine interacts with and it maps onto people's self-reported caffeine sensitivities.\n\n2. Xia, E. H., Zhang, H. Bin, Sheng, J., Li, K., Zhang, Q. J., Kim, C., et al. (2017). The Tea Tree Genome Provides Insights into Tea Flavor and Independent Evolution of Caffeine Biosynthesis. Mol. Plant 10, 866\u2013877. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.molp.2017.04.002\n\nThis paper discusses the evolution of the genes needed to produce caffeine.  Caffeine production likely evolved separately in tea, coffee, and cocoa, rather than being inherited from a common ancestor.  Caffeine is probably a really effective insecticide if many different lineages arrived at the same solution independently.\n\n3. Friedman, M., Kim, S. Y., Lee, S. J., Han, G. P., Han, J. S., Lee, K. R., et al. (2005). Distribution of catechins, theaflavins, caffeine, and theobromine in 77 teas consumed in the United States. J. Food Sci. 70, C550\u2013C559. Available at: http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2621.2005.tb08304.x/abstract.\n\nIn this paper, the authors compare the catechins and caffeine content of 77 teas, mostly bagged, commodity teas.  It looks like, on average, the black teas in their study had higher caffeine than the green teas (figure 5), but note that many of their green teas are blended (genmaicha), not leaves (kukicha), or decaffeinated.  Even so, several green teas are higher in caffeine than several black teas.  \n\n4. Lin, Y.-S., Tsai, Y.-J., Tsay, J.-S., and Lin, J.-K. (2003). Factors Affecting the Levels of Tea Polyphenols and Caffeine in Tea Leaves. J. Agric. Food Chem. 51, 1864\u20131873. https://doi.org/10.1021/jf021066b.\n\nThis paper shows that regardless of tea type, young leaves have higher caffeine content than old leaves (table 4) and that caffeine content decreases as you go down the stem from the bud (older leaves have less caffeine) (figure 5).", "tags": ["tea", "caffeine", "#teasciencetuesday"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT28M47S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "20", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "314", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "7"}, "id": "TF5kjjDs4Tg"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2017.04.002"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.im.2017.04.002", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "MUDAH dan GRATIS download Jurnal International yang Berbayar", "channelId": "UCftPy5sLwKJICiJ2lzynIHA", "channelTitle": "Gudang Ilmu", "publishedAt": "2017-10-01T13:49:46Z", "description": "Bagi yang kesulitan untuk download jurnal internasional yang berbayar. video ini solusinya", "tags": ["Jurnal", "Jurnal Internasional", "Gratis", "Penelitian", "Dikti", "Kemenristekdikti", "Download Jurnal"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M5S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "2", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "53", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "yS9BIFWnIeo"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2017.04.002"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.im.2017.04.002", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Direct Metal Laser Sintering (DMLS) simulation using LIGGGHTS - temperature distribuation", "channelId": "UCBdD2Y126a--CboThRvvSVw", "channelTitle": "Jing Zhang", "publishedAt": "2016-06-21T23:10:05Z", "description": "Direct Metal Laser Sintering (DMLS) simulation using LIGGGHTS, discrete element modeling code. Er ist dort Professor f\u00fcr Kommunikationswissenschaft mit Schwerpunkt Medienrealit\u00e4t besch\u00e4ftigt sich unter anderem mit dem Themen wie Mediatisierung und Medienkultur, \u00d6ffentlichkeits- und Partizipationsforschung sowie  Virtualisierung und digitale Methoden \n\n360\u00b0-Videos haben schon Einzug in die Medienp\u00e4dagogik gehalten, es werden 3D-Spiele mit Jugendlichen entwickelt und VR-Brillen aus Pappe gebastelt.\n\nDiese Angebote sind nur ein Bruchteil dessen, was in und mit Digitalen Bildungswelten m\u00f6glich ist. Wir wollen im Webtalk gemeinsam nach weiteren Praxisbeispielen und Methoden suchen. Nach einer Definition und Einf\u00fchrung geht es um die Fragestellungen, wie digitale Bildungswelten beschaffen sein m\u00fcssen, welche technischen L\u00f6sungen und M\u00f6glichkeiten es gibt und wie sie medienp\u00e4dagogisch eingesetzt werden k\u00f6nnen.\n\nEin Talk der \"Fachgruppe Netzpolitik\" in der GMK - Gesellschaft f\u00fcr Medienp\u00e4dagogik und Kommunikationskultur.", "tags": Juan Leyton- Fonopedia Audiovestibular", "channelId": "UCXdRfjzvDJvj4CdXQ5c3IuQ", "channelTitle": "FONOPEDIA FONOAUDIOLOGIA UC TEMUCO", "publishedAt": "2018-10-16T19:18:17Z", "description": "El proyecto Fonopedia de la carrera de Fonoaudiolog\u00eda de la Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Temuco, perteneciente al Departamento de Procesos Terap\u00e9uticos de la Facultad de Ciencias de la Salud es un proyecto sin fines de lucro que pretende disminuir las barreras de acceso a la Pr\u00e1ctica Basada en la Evidencia en Fonoaudiolog\u00eda, a trav\u00e9s de una aplicaci\u00f3n m\u00f3vil de diagn\u00f3sticos fonoaudiol\u00f3gicos, recomendaciones de evaluaci\u00f3n e intervenci\u00f3n fonoaudiol\u00f3gica basada en la evidencia cient\u00edfica. \nEl equipo del proyecto est\u00e1 conformado por: \nFlgo. Los est\u00e1ndares de grabaci\u00f3n y edici\u00f3n fueron otorgados por la Direcci\u00f3n de Tecnolog\u00edas Educativas de la Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Temuco. \nEl proyecto est\u00e1 abierto a nuevas colaboraciones a medida que sea necesario actualizar la evidencia cient\u00edfica existente, por lo que se admiten futuras colaboraciones para seguir potenciando la Fonoaudiolog\u00eda en Iberoam\u00e9rica. Colaborador\nFlgo. Pablo Carrasco. Colaborador\nFlga. Claudia Bascu\u00f1\u00e1n. Colaboradora. \n\nEste proyecto fue financiado por la Direcci\u00f3n General de Docencia de la Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Temuco en un proyecto docente adjudicado en 2016. Los est\u00e1ndares de grabaci\u00f3n y edici\u00f3n fueron otorgados por la Direcci\u00f3n de Tecnolog\u00edas Educativas de la Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Temuco. \nEl proyecto est\u00e1 abierto a nuevas colaboraciones a medida que sea necesario actualizar la evidencia cient\u00edfica existente, por lo que se admiten futuras colaboraciones para seguir potenciando la Fonoaudiolog\u00eda en Iberoam\u00e9rica. \uc790\uc8fc \uad8c\uc7a5\ub429\ub2c8\ub2e4. \uc6b4\ub3d9\uc740 \ud608\uc555\uc744 \ub0ae\ucd94\ub294\ub370\uc694, \uc77c\uba85 Post-exercise hypotension (PEH) \uc6b4\ub3d9 \ud6c4 \uc2dd\uc774\uc9c8\uc0b0\uc5fc\uc774 \uc0b0\ud654\uc9c8\uc18c-no\ub85c \ubc14\ub00c\uae30 \ub54c\ubb38\uc5d0 \ud608\uc555\uc5d0 \ub3c4\uc6c0\uc744 \uc8fc\uace0 \uc6b4\ub3d9 \uc2dc \ud38c\ud551\uacfc \uc218\ucd95\uae30 \ud608\uc555\uc774 \ub5a8\uc5b4\uc9c0\ub294 \uac83 \ubfd0\ub9cc\uc774 \uc544\ub2c8\ub77c \uc6b4\ub3d9 \uc911\uc5d0 \uadfc\uc721\uc5d0 \uc0b0\uc18c\uc640 \uc601\uc591\uc18c\uac00 \ubc15\ud14c\ub9ac\uc544, \ud56d\uade0 \uac00\uae00 \uc774 \uc774\uc57c\uae30\ub97c \uc65c \ud588\ub290\ub0d0! \uc5f0\uad6c\ub4e4\uc744 \ubcf4\uaca0\uc2b5\ub2c8\ub2e4.\n\n\ud608\uc555\uc744 "10.1016/j.media.2017.09.004"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.media.2017.09.004", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Velociraptor: Your Dinosaurs Are Wrong #24", "channelId": "UCmVa-cbCpkd5Cd9Fr_4tCWg", Are saturated fat foods healthy or harmful? The science on saturated vs unsaturated fat foods, the controversies and the exceptions.\n\nSubscribe for more free nutrition and health tips: https://bit.ly/2toMJ9u\n\nConnect with me:\nFacebook: https://www.facebook.com/DrGilCarvalho/\nTwitter: https://twitter.com/NutritionMadeS3\nAnimations: Even Topland @toplandmedia\n\nSaturated vs unsaturated fat, let's make sense of fats!\n\nSaturated fat is concentrated in animal foods and some plant products like coconut oil while Unsaturated fat is concentrated in plants.\n\nSaturated fat raises cholesterol levels. But does it cause heart disease?\nClassical studies linked saturated fat and heart disease, so saturated fat was widely seen as a problem until a media storm a few years ago. Was saturated fat fine after all? \n\nIn 2 studies, people eating less saturated fat had just as much cardiovascular disease. So maybe saturated fat is not a factor?\n\nHarvard study: People who eat less saturated fat and more unsaturated fat instead have lower risk. Those who eat more whole grains instead also had lower risk. But refined grains were no better than saturated fat.\n\nBut maybe they eat less saturated fat, less cheese and meat and also smoke less and exercise more. How do we know the saturated fat has anything to do with them being healthier? A brand new study found people told to eat less  saturated fat have less cardiovascular disease. It wasn\u2019t clear which food replacements were best but less  saturated fat led to less risk. They found no harmful effects of reducing saturated fat.\nSaturated fat always raises emotions. I used to eat a lot more saturated fat and gradually adapted. Others might make a different decision.\n\nThis means favoring unprocessed plant foods which are low in saturated vs unsaturated fats. Fish is also a wise choice due to the balance of saturated vs unsaturated fat. Some types of saturated fat are worse than others. We covered dietary patterns low in saturated fat and high in unsaturated fats in previous videos.\n\nReferences:\nsaturated fat and serum cholesterol levels: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2125600/\nAHA Advisory: https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/full/10.1161/CIR.0000000000000510\n2 studies that generated the media storm:\nhttps://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24723079/\nhttps://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20071648/\nHarvard study:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4593072/\nrecent randomized trial (Cochrane): www.cochranelibrary.com/cdsr/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD011737.pub2/full\nstearic acid doesn't raise LDL-c: https://academic.oup.com/ajcn/article/77/5/1146/4689813\nchocolate and risk:\nhttps://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S089990071730206X\nhttps://www.mdpi.com/2072-6643/9/7/688\n\nDisclaimer: The contents of this video are for informational purposes only and are not intended to be medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment, nor to replace medical care. "defaultLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "MinuteEarth", "publishedAt": "2017-12-06T17:09:45Z", "description": "Thanks to 23andMe for sponsoring this video! http://www.23andme.com/minuteearth\nIf you live outside the US, click here: https://www.23andme.com/\n\nWhen we domesticate an animal species, their brains shrink and they freak out less.\n\nThanks also to our supporters on https://www.patreon.com/MinuteEarth\n\nAnd to our SPONSORS on YouTube.\n___________________________________________\n\nTo learn more, start your googling with these keywords: \nDomesticated animal: a species of animal bred by humans over generations to become nonreactive and gain characteristics suitable for life as a farm animal or pet\n\nTame animal: an individual animal raised in a way that it has become less dangerous and frightened of people\n\nFeral animal: an animal that escapes from captivity or domestication (& regains some similar & some different characteristics compared to its pre-domesticated state)\n\n\"Fight or flight\": an instinctive physiological response to a threatening situation that readies a creature to either to resist forcibly or escape\n\nLimbic system: the brain\u2019s \u201cpanic button\u201d - a system of nerves and networks near the bottom of the cortex that controls basic emotions (e.g. fear, pleasure, anger) and drives (e.g. hunger, sex, dominance)\n\nTelencephalon: the most developed and anterior part of the forebrain, consisting chiefly of the cerebral hemispheres, and the brain region that shrinks most in domesticated animals\n\nDomestication: a sustained multigenerational, mutualistic relationship in which one species (e.g. humans) assumes a significant degree of influence over the reproduction and care of another species (e.g. cows) in order to secure a more predictable supply of a resource of interest (e.g. milk/meat/traction), and through which the domesticated organisms gain advantage over individuals that remain outside this relationship (e.g. aurochs, which went extinct), thereby benefitting and often increasing the fitness of both species involved\n___________________________________________\n\nIf What makes human different from other animals is that we have the ability to think about how we think. This means the ability to plan, set goals, and analyze. A lack of self awareness causes us to become self-destructive and to put ourselves in toxic or unhealthy situations. You do not want to be on auto-pilot or a robot do you? What makes us unique and grow is our ability to be self aware. And that's why psych2go's videos aim to help us learn more about ourselves. \n\nAre you looking for tips on how to be more self aware? The first step towards being self aware is to learn more about it and recognize the signs we might be lacking self awareness.  \n\nDid you know that self-love requires self awareness? Deixe seu like e ative as notifica\u00e7\u00f5es do canal!", "publishedAt": "2020-04-27T15:39:56Z", "title": "Revis\u00e3o Sistem\u00e1tica e Metan\u00e1lise", "channelId": "UC1TRSl9kf8Rgfo1NmvzAxGg", "channelTitle": "Dissertare Assessoria"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT43M3S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "56", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "NdD6e7rStQE"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2017.10.003"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.media.2017.10.003", "items": [{"snippet": {"description": "Indexing predation / scavenging around shellfish reefs using standardised field assays (\u2018squidpops\u2019). \r\n\nThis video shows how we use \u2018squidpops\u2019 (a type of baited underwater camera system) to measure predation / scavenging rates and to identify consumers in field assays at restored shellfish reefs and control sites. \r\n\n\u2018Squidpops\u2019 are now a standard method for indexing relative predation rates of marine mesopredators, and have been used extensively for this purpose in coastal seascapes (Refs 1,2,3)  In essence, squidpops are baited under-water remote video stations (BRUVs), but have the major advantage that the same bait (and mostly also the same camera system) is used by scientists globally: this makes data directly comparable between locations and allows us to examine questions at large scales by a network of collaborators.  \r\n\n\u201cSquidpops\u201d consist of a single 1 cm^2 piece of dried squid mantle tethered to a 20 cm long bamboo stake using a 10 cm length of fishing line. Camera units comprised a 5 kg weight with a GoPro camera recording in high definition (1080p). The squidpop stake was fastened to the camera unit using a 15mm gauge PVC arm at a distance of 45 cm from the camera, so that the bait was visible at all times. \r\n\nDuring a recent study in the Noosa River Estuary (Australia) we deployed 384 squidpops at restored shellfish reefs and at matched control sites (Ref 3).  All deployments were made on bare substrate (i.e. not in seagrass meadows or mangrove forests). To maximise the probability of good visibility (water clarity), all assays were run within 2 hours either side of high tide (see also Ref 4).  Each baited camera recorded for one hour.  \r\n\nThe results demonstrate that predation is significantly higher at restored reefs and the presence and extent of nearby seagrass and mangroves suppresses consumption rates (i.e. reefs have more predation when located on bare sand; Ref 3).  \r\n\nREFERENCES\r\n1 - Duffy JE, Ziegler SL, Campbell JE, Bippus PM, Lefcheck JS (2015) Squidpops: a simple tool to crowdsource a global map of marine predation intensity. PLoS One 10, e0142994. \r\n\n2 - Rodemann JR, Brandl SJ (2017) Consumption pressure in coastal marine environments decreases with latitude and in artificial vs. natural habitats. Marine Ecology Progress Series 574, 167\u2013179. \r\n\n3 - Duncan CK, Gilby BL, Olds AD, Connolly RM, Ortodossi NL, Henderson CJ, and Schlacher TA (2019) Landscape context modifies the rate and distribution of predation around habitat restoration sites. Biological Conservation 237:97-104.  \r\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.biocon.2019.06.028\r\n\n4 \u2013 Gilby BL, Olds AD, Connolly RM, Yabsley NA, Maxwell PS, Tibbetts IR, Schoeman DS, Schlacher TA (2017) Umbrellas can work underwater: using threatened species as indicator and management surrogates can improve coastal conservation. Estuarine Coastal Shelf Science. 199: 132\u2013140. \r\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecss.2017.10.003 \r\n\nREEF RESTORATION KEYWORDS\r\n\nreefs, restoration, oysters, oyster reefs, habitat creation, Ecology", "publishedAt": "2017-11-16T20:07:15Z", "description": "We documented American Eels (Anguilla rostrata) switching their typical nighttime, nonselective bottom feeding behavior to daytime, targeted selection on upstream-migrating goby postlarvae in Caribbean rivers (Puerto Rico). These are small, young fish (1-2 inches) with suction-cup-shaped fins (to climb rocks) that migrate from the ocean up the rivers once a month -- Eels love to snack on them! \n\nA note about this behavior was published in the journal Food Webs:\n\nEngman, A.C., J.R. Retrieved from http://www.shrinktank.com/violent-video-games-violence-psychologist-answers/", "tags": ["parody", "violence in games", "news story"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M23S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "12", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "lyA6rVnAQWo"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2017.10.003"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.media.2017.10.003", "items": [{"snippet": {"description": "A. Khalaf, M. Sybeldon, E. Sejdi\u0107, M. Akcakaya, \u201cA brain-computer interface based on functional transcranial Doppler ultrasound using wavelet transform and support vector machines,\u201d Journal of Neuroscience Methods, vol. 293, pp. 174-182, Jan. 2018.\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.jneumeth.2017.10.003\n\n\n\nABSTRACT:\n\nBACKGROUND: Functional transcranial Doppler (fTCD) is an ultrasound based neuroimaging technique used to assess neural activation that occurs during a cognitive task through measuring velocity of cerebral blood flow. NEW METHOD: The objective of this paper is to investigate the feasibility of a 2-class and 3-class real-time BCI based on blood flow velocity in left and right middle cerebral arteries in response to mental rotation and word generation tasks. Statistical features based on a five-level wavelet decomposition were extracted from the fTCD signals. The Wilcoxon test and support vector machines (SVM), with a linear kernel, were employed for feature reduction and classification. RESULTS: The experimental results showed that within approximately 3s of the onset of the cognitive task average accuracies of 80.29%, and 82.35% were obtained for the mental rotation versus resting state and the word generation versus resting state respectively. The mental rotation task versus word generation task achieved an average accuracy of 79.72% within 2.24s from the onset of the cognitive task. Furthermore, an average accuracy of 65.27% was obtained for the 3-class problem within 4.68s. COMPARISON WITH EXISTING METHODS: The results presented here provide significant improvement compared to the relevant fTCD-based systems presented in literature in terms of accuracy and speed. Specifically, the reported speed in this manuscript is at least 12 and 2.5 times faster than any existing binary and 3-class fTCD-based BCIs, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: These results show fTCD as a promising and viable candidate to be used towards developing a real-time BCI.\n\n\n#brain #datascience #machinelearning #supportvectormachines #neuroscience "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "March 17, 2020: Exploring the Interactions between Water, Climate and Communication", "channelId": "UCIbosebk4Rh4LLEMKH_Q4Uw", "channelTitle": "Ohio State Environmental Professionals Network", "publishedAt": "2020-03-20T19:23:25Z", "description": "On Tuesday March 17, EPN hosted a Zoom Webinar-based program instead of our standard EPN in-person breakfast program. \n\nThis EPN Zoom Webinar-based program, co-hosted with the Water Management Association of Ohio (WMAO), the Ohio Water Resources Center, and TerrAqua (a multi-disciplinary student organization at Ohio State), occurred through an online format instead of our standard EPN in-person breakfast program. \n\nNumerous research agencies, including the U.S. Global Change Research Program, find that in the U.S. Midwest a variety of weather-related challenges are currently, and will increasingly, impact our local communities through such issues as extreme precipitation events and flooding, decreases in lake ice and snow cover, and increases in urban heat islands and drought nca2018.globalchange.gov/chapter/21/). These water-climate relationships are complex, dynamic and can be challenging to communicate. \n\nJoin this program as we learn about the interactions between the water cycle, changing weather patterns, and how to understand and communicate these issues in natural resource management. This program is in alignment with the March 22, 2020 World Water Day theme, which is \u201cabout water and climate change \u2013 and how the two are inextricably linked.\u201d (learn more at worldwaterday.org). Thanks to our colleagues at the Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center at Ohio State for helping to frame this program\u2019s agenda.\n\nThis program features: \n\nJoe Campbell, Ph.D. director, EPN, Hannah Comune, president, TerrAqua, and Eugene Braig, program director of aquatic ecosystems (SENR) and board president, WMAO, provide welcome remarks and program introduction\n\nBryan Mark, Ph.D., professor, Department of Geography and State Climatologist of Ohio, and Michael Durand, Ph.D., professor, School of Earth Sciences, present on the changing cryosphere in Earth's water cycle\n\nKim Channell, climatologist, Great Lakes Integrated Sciences and Assessments presents Climate Change in the Great Lakes \n\nRobyn Wilson, Ph.D., professor, SENR, presents Communicating climate change and promoting action in the Great Lakes\n\nAudience Q & A with Dr. Durand, Ms. Channell, and Dr. Wilson\n\nConcluding remarks by Jeff Sharp, Ph.D., director, School of Environment and Natural Resources, and Karina Peggau, education and outreach program coordinator, Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2H2M2S"}, "statistics": But for tens of millions of years, they were just an odd collection of tiny bottom feeders. However, once bilateral symmetry evolved, it was poised and ready to seize the stage. This moment in time is known as \u201cthe Cambrian Explosion\u201d.  But how exactly did bilaterians manage to take over in the end? What kickstarted the Cambrian Explosion and can we expect the same thing to happen in alien biospheres? Was the Cambrian Explosion destined to happen or just a fortunate fluke? Would bilaterally symmetrical animals always evolve on Earth-like worlds? Let\u2019s try to find out!\n\nCHAPTERS\n0:00 Introduction\n1:07 Origin of Bilaterians\n3:25 Causes of the Cambrian Explosion\n7:20 Universal Trends for Planetary Biospheres\n10:17 Alien Biosphere Evolution \n11:37 Closing thoughts\n\nSOCIAL MEDIA: \nTwitter: https://twitter.com/Phrenotopian\nReddit: https://www.reddit.com/r/phrenotopia/\n\nREFERENCES \n - Prieto-Barajas CM et al (2018) \"Microbial mat ecosystems: Structure types, functional diversity, and biotechnological application\" Electronic Journal of Biotechnology - 31, 48-56 |  https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ejbt.2017.11.001\n - Hoyal Cuthill JF & Morris SC (2017) \"Nutrient-dependent growth underpinned the Ediacaran transition to large body size.\" Nature Ecology and Evolution 1, 1201-1204\n - Bobrovskiy et al. "10.1016/j.media.2017.11.002", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Chemotherapie bei Brustkrebs: Unterst\u00fctzung durch Genexpressionstest", "channelId": "UCNEAIEBaQ1qaXomLin4Z-Fw", "defaultLanguage": "de", "channelTitle": "NeoDoc", "publishedAt": "2017-12-05T09:24:41Z", "description": "U\u0308ber Brustkrebs im Fru\u0308hstadium und Oncotype DX\nDer Oncotype DX Brustkrebstest ist der einzige genomische Test, der sowohl fu\u0308r eine sichere Aussage u\u0308ber den zu erwartenden Nutzen einer Chemotherapie als auch u\u0308ber das Ru\u0308ckfallrisiko bei Brustkrebs im Fru\u0308hstadium validiert ist. Brustkrebs ist in Europa die unter Frauen meistverbreitete Krebsart. Sie tritt bei vielen in der Lebensphase auf, in der sie sich der Karriere und der Familie widmen. Obwohl Patientinnen ha\u0308ufig eine Chemotherapie empfohlen wird, konnten Studien zeigen, dass weniger als 10 % der Patientinnen mit Brustkrebs im Fru\u0308hstadium von einer Chemotherapie profitieren.\n\nDer Oncotype DX wurde entwickelt, um auf Grundlage von Informationen u\u0308ber die Biologie des individuellen Brustkrebses eine sinnvolle Therapieentscheidung zu treffen und die Behandlung individuell abzustimmen. Der Test verringert die Anzahl der unno\u0308tigen Chemotherapien und die damit einhergehenden Kosten fu\u0308r das Gesundheitswesen signifikant. Eine deutsche Analyse aus dem Jahr 2017 scha\u0308tzt die mo\u0308glichen Einsparungen bei den gesamtgesellschaftlichen Kosten durch den Test auf mehr als 253 Millionen Euro pro Jahr.\n\nOncotype DX ist in den wichtigsten internationalen Leitlinien enthalten und wird von verschiedenen Gesundheitssystemen in Europa erstattet. Nach Bewertung und Empfehlung durch das NICE im Jahr 2013 ist der Test fu\u0308r alle britischen Patientinnen mittlerweile sehr gut verfu\u0308gbar. Patientinnen in Frankreich ko\u0308nnen den Oncotype DX dank eines speziellen Finanzierungsmodells fu\u0308r innovative Diagnostik nutzen. In Europa erstatten u. a. die Schweiz, Irland, Griechenland und Spanien den Test.\n\n\u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \n\u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \n\nWeitere Informationen erh\u00e4ltst du:\n\u00dcber den Oncotype DX: www.oncotypeiq.de\nWeitere Artikel \u00fcber Brustkrebs: https://medizin-aspekte.de/?s=brustkrebs\n\n\u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \n\u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \n\n\u25ba Facebook: https://goo.gl/2SFUHw\n\u25ba YouTube: https://goo.gl/HgQTtf\n\u25ba Twitter: https://goo.gl/Gu3K6a\n\u25ba Website: https://goo.gl/MERqA4\n\n\u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \n\u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014\n\nQuellen / Publikationen:\n\nIKK BB - Innungskrankenkasse Brandenburg und Berlin (PM, 04.12.17)\n\nEUCAN. 2012. \u5ff5\u4f5b\u5171\u4fee\u958b\u793a\u66a8\u5206\u4eab\n\n\u4ee5\u4e0b\u5c31\u5f71\u7247\u6240\u5206\u4eab\u7684\u5167\u5bb9\u505a\u4e9b\u8a31\u4fee\u6b63\u548c\u88dc\u5145\u8aaa\u660e\uff1a\n\n\u4e00\u3001\u4fee\u6b63\u5167\u5bb9\n(\u4e00)\u597d\u7684\u8102\u80aa- \u4e0d\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa\uff1a\u518d\u7d30\u5206\u70ba\u55ae\u5143\u4e0d\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa(monounsaturated fat)\u548c\u591a\u5143\u4e0d\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa(polyunsaturated fat)\uff0c\u4e0d\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa\u542b\u91cf\u9ad8\u7684\u98df\u7269\u5305\u62ec\u786c\u6bbc\u679c(\u8170\u679ccashew\u3001\u674f\u4ec1almond\u3001\u82b1\u751fpeanut\u7b49)\u3001\u690d\u7269\u6cb9(\u4f8b\u5982\u82a5\u82b1\u5b50canola\u3001\u6a44\u6b16olive\u3001\u82b1\u751f\u3001\u7d05\u82b1safflower\u3001\u829d\u9ebbsesame\u3001\u8475\u82b1sunflower\u7b49)\u3001\u725b\u6cb9\u679c(avocado)\u3001\u4e9e\u9ebb\u5b50flaxseed \u3001\u5927\u8c46soybean)\u7b49\u3002\n\n\u7814\u7a76\u986f\u793a\u98df\u7528\u4e0d\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa\u4ee3\u66ff\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa\u548c\u53cd\u5f0f\u8102\u80aa\u80fd\u964d\u4f4e\u60a3\u4e0a\u51a0\u5fc3\u75c5\u7684\u98a8\u96aa\u3002\u4e0d\u904e\uff0c\u98df\u7528\u904e\u91cf\u4e0d\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa\u4e5f\u6703\u589e\u52a0\u651d\u53d6\u7684\u71b1\u91cf(calories)\uff0c\u5c0e\u81f4\u9ad4\u91cd\u4e0a\u6607\u800c\u589e\u52a0\u60a3\u4e0a\u80a5\u80d6\u75c7\u3001\u4e8c\u578b\u7cd6\u5c3f\u75c5\u3001\u51a0\u5fc3\u75c5\u548c\u67d0\u4e9b\u764c\u75c5\u7684\u98a8\u96aa\u3002\n\n(\u4e8c)\u58de\u7684\u8102\u80aa-\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa\uff1a\u7814\u7a76\u986f\u793a\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa\u6703\u589e\u52a0\u4eba\u9ad4\u5167\u4f4e\u5bc6\u5ea6\u8102\u86cb\u767d\u81bd\u56fa\u9187(low density lipoprotein cholesterol \u7c21\u7a31LDL-cholesterol)\uff0c\u5373\u662f\u6703\u589e\u52a0\u60a3\u4e0a\u51a0\u5fc3\u75c5\u7684\u300c\u58de\u81bd\u56fa\u9187\u300d\uff0c\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa\u542b\u91cf\u9ad8\u7684\u98df\u54c1\u5305\u62ec\u8089\u985e(\u725b\u3001\u8c6c\u3001\u7f8a\u3001\u96de\u7b49)\u3001\u6930\u5b50\u6cb9\u3001\u68d5\u6ada\u6cb9\u3001\u5976\u985e\u98df\u54c1(\u4f8b\u5982\u725b\u6cb9\u3001\u829d\u58eb\u3001\u5168\u8102\u5976\u7b49)\u3001\u8d77\u9165\u6cb9(shortening)\u7b49\uff0c\u9078\u7528\u7626\u8089\u3001\u4f4e\u8102\u5976\u985e\u98df\u54c1\u7b49\u80fd\u6e1b\u4f4e\u98f2\u98df\u4e2d\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa\u7684\u4efd\u91cf\u3002\n\n(\u4e09)\u52a3\u8cea\u7684\u8102\u80aa \u2014 \u53cd\u5f0f\u8102\u80aa\uff1a\u5982\u540c\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa\uff0c\u53cd\u5f0f\u8102\u80aa\u6703\u589e\u52a0\u4eba\u9ad4\u5167\u4f4e\u5bc6\u5ea6\u8102\u86cb\u767d\u81bd\u56fa\u9187(\u5373\u58de\u81bd\u56fa\u9187)\uff0c\u4f46\u8207\u98fd\u548c\u8102\u80aa\u4e0d\u540c\uff0c\u53cd\u5f0f\u8102\u80aa\u4ea6\u6703\u964d\u4f4e\u4eba\u9ad4\u5167\u9ad8\u5bc6\u5ea6\u8102\u86cb\u767d\u81bd\u56fa\u9187(high density lipoprotein cholesterol \u7c21\u7a31HDL-cholesterol\u5373\u597d\u81bd\u56fa\u9187)\uff0c\u5169\u8005\u90fd\u80fd\u589e\u52a0\u60a3\u4e0a\u51a0\u5fc3\u75c5\u7684\u98a8\u96aa\u3002\n\n\u53cd\u5f0f\u8102\u80aa\u662f\u5728\u5c07\u6db2\u9ad4\u8102\u80aa\u8f49\u70ba\u56fa\u9ad4\u8102\u80aa\u7684\u300c\u90e8\u4efd\u6c2b\u5316\u300d(partial hydrogenation)\u904e\u7a0b\u4e2d\u7522\u751f\uff0c\u4f7f\u7528\u53cd\u5f0f\u8102\u80aa\u4f7f\u98df\u7269\u8f03\u4e0d\u5bb9\u6613\u8150\u58de\uff0c\u4ee4\u552e\u8ce3\u7684\u98df\u54c1\u6709\u8f03\u9577\u7684\u8ca8\u67b6\u671f(shelf life\u5373\u5546\u54c1\u5132\u653e\u4e0d\u8b8a\u8cea\u7684\u671f\u9650)\u548c\u770b\u4f86\u53ca\u5403\u7684\u6642\u5019\u611f\u89ba\u8f03\u4e0d\u6cb9\u81a9\uff0c\u53cd\u5f0f\u8102\u80aa\u542b\u91cf\u9ad8\u7684\u98df\u7269\u5305\u62ec\u4eba\u9020\u725b\u6cb9\u3001\u714e\u70b8\u98df\u7269(\u4f8b\u5982\u85af\u7247\u3001\u70b8\u85af\u689d\u7b49)\u3001\u7cd5\u9905(\u5305\u62ec\u9905\u4e7e\u3001\u86cb\u7cd5\u3001\u725b\u89d2\u5305croissants\u3001\u66f2\u5947cookies\u3001\u751c\u5708\u5708doughnuts\u3001\u7f8e\u5f0f\u9b06\u9905muffins\u7b49)\u7b49\u3002\n\n\n\u4e8c\u3001\u88dc\u5145\u8aaa\u660e\n\u7d14\u7d20\u98f2\u98df\u88e1\u7684\u690d\u5316\u7d20\uff08Phytochemicals\uff09\uff0c\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u70ba\u690d\u7269\u7684\u514d\u75ab\u7cfb\u7d71\uff0c\u5b83\u662f\u690d\u7269\u751f\u9577\u7684\u5fc5\u8981\u5143\u7d20\uff0c\u4e5f\u662f\u690d\u7269\u4e94\u984f\u516d\u8272\u4e4b\u5929\u7136\u8272\u7d20\u548c\u690d\u7269\u6c23\u5473\u4e4b\u7269\u8cea\u4f86\u6e90\u3002\n\n\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u4f5c\u7528\uff1a\n\uff08\u4e00\uff09\u63d0\u4f9b\u690d\u7269\u81ea\u6211\u4fdd\u8b77\u7684\u529f\u80fd\uff0c\u62b5\u6297\u6606\u87f2\u3001\u7d30\u83cc\u3001\u771f\u83cc\u3001\u75c5\u6bd2\u7684\u611f\u67d3\u50b7\u5bb3\u3002\n\uff08\u4e8c\uff09\u5c0d\u7d2b\u5916\u7dda\uff0c\u8f3b\u5c04\u7dda\uff0c\u7a7a\u6c23\u53ca\u571f\u58e4\u6c61\u67d3\uff0c\u5316\u5b78\u85e5\u7269\u4e4b\u7a2e\u7a2e\u50b7\u5bb3\u4e4b\u4fdd\u8b77\u4f5c\u7528\u3002\n\n\u5c0d\u4eba\u985e\u800c\u8a00\uff0c\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u96d6\u5c6c\u300c\u975e\u5fc5\u8981\u6027\u71df\u990a\u7d20\u300d\u4f46\u56e0\u4eba\u9ad4\u672c\u8eab\u7121\u6cd5\u88fd\u9020\u690d\u5316\u7d20\uff0c\u5fc5\u9808\u5f9e\u5404\u7a2e\u98df\u7269\u4f86\u651d\u53d6\u9019\u4e9b\u6709\u76ca\u4eba\u9ad4\u5065\u5eb7\u7684\u71df\u990a\u6210\u5206\uff0c\u7d71\u7a31\u690d\u7269\u71df\u990a\u7d20\uff08phytonutrient\uff09\uff0c\u4ea6\u6709\u300c21\u4e16\u7d00\u7684\u7dad\u751f\u7d20\u300d\u4e4b\u7a31\u3002\n\n\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u5c0d\u4eba\u9ad4\u7684\u4f5c\u7528\uff0c\u5404\u7a2e\u4e0d\u540c\u7684\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u5c0d\u4eba\u9ad4\u6709\u4e0d\u540c\u7684\u529f\u80fd\uff0c\u5982\uff1a\n\uff08\u4e00\uff09\u5f37\u529b\u7684\u6297\u6c27\u5316\u7269\u8cea\uff0c\u53ef\u6e05\u9664\u81ea\u7531\u57fa\uff0c\u6d3b\u5316\u514d\u75ab\u6a5f\u80fd\uff0c\u589e\u5f37\u514d\u75ab\u529b\uff0c\u8f14\u52a9\u7dad\u751f\u7d20\u767c\u63ee\u751f\u7406\u6a5f\u80fd\uff0c\u6fc0\u767c\u9ad4\u5167\u9175\u7d20\u89e3\u6bd2\u6d3b\u6027\uff0c\u8abf\u7bc0\u7522\u751f\u9175\u7d20\uff0c\u9810\u9632\u7d30\u80de\u53d7\u640d\u3002\n\uff08\u4e8c\uff09\u6539\u5584\u8840\u6d41\u5faa\u74b0\uff0c\u6291\u5236\u767c\u708e\u53ca\u904e\u654f\uff0c\u62b5\u6297\u7d30\u83cc\u53ca\u75c5\u6bd2\u611f\u67d3\uff0c\u6e1b\u5c11\u7f79\u764c\u98a8\u96aa\u3002\u5c0d\u6cbb\u7642\u8207\u9810\u9632\u6162\u6027\u75be\u75c5\uff0c\u5982\u9ad8\u8840\u58d3\u3001\u7cd6\u5c3f\u75c5\u3001\u80a5\u80d6\u75c7\u3001\u9aa8\u8cea\u758f\u9b06\u3001\u5fc3\u8840\u7ba1\u75c5\u7686\u6709\u52a9\u76ca\u3002\n\uff08\u4e09\uff09\u6539\u5584\u7761\u7720\u3001\u8a18\u61b6\uff0c\u6539\u5584\u9ad4\u8cea\uff0c\u4fc3\u9032\u5065\u5eb7\u9577\u58fd\uff0c\u5373\u70ba\u589e\u5f37\u514d\u75ab\uff0c\u6297\u8001\u53ca\u9632\u764c\u3002\n\n\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u5982\u4f55\u9810\u9632\u548c\u6291\u5236\u764c\u75c7\n\uff08\u4e00\uff09\u63d0\u9ad8\u4eba\u9ad4\u514d\u75ab\u529b: \u5404\u7a2e\u690d\u7269\u4e4b\u591a\u91a3\u9ad4\uff0c\u53ef\u589e\u52a0\u81ea\u7136\u6bba\u624b\u7d30\u80de\u53ca\uff34\u7d30\u80de\u3001\u6d3b\u5316\u5de8\u566c\u7d30\u80de\u3001\u5206\u6ccc\u816b\u7624\u58de\u6b7b\u56e0\u5b50\u3001\u7522\u751f\u767d\u4ecb\u7d20\u3001\u5e72\u64fe\u7d20\u3001\u6dcb\u5df4\u7403\u53ca\u4fc3\u9032\u6297\u9ad4\u7522\u751f\u7b49\uff0c\u4f86\u6291\u5236\u764c\u75c7\u6210\u9577\u3002\n\uff08\u4e8c\uff09\u8a98\u5c0e\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u8d70\u5411\u826f\u6027\u5206\u5316: \u4f7f\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u7531\u60e1\u6027\u8f49\u70ba\u826f\u6027\uff0c\u4e26\u4e0d\u518d\u5206\u88c2\u53ca\u6210\u9577\u3002\n\uff08\u4e09\uff09\u6291\u5236\u764c\u8840\u7ba1\u65b0\u751f: \u4f7f\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u6210\u9577\u7684\u8840\u6d41\u71df\u990a\u4f9b\u61c9\u505c\u6b62\uff0c\u800c\u4e0d\u518d\u751f\u9577\u4e26\u907f\u514d\u8f49\u79fb\u3002\n\uff08\u56db\uff09\u4fc3\u9032\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u8d70\u5411\u51cb\u4ea1\uff0c\u4e26\u63a7\u5236\u5176\u6210\u9577\u3002\n\uff08\u4e94\uff09\u6297\u6c27\u5316\uff08\u6216\u6297\u81ea\u7531\u57fa\uff09\u7684\u4f5c\u7528\uff0c \u85c9\u5176\u6297\u6c27\u5316\u4f5c\u7528\uff0c\u4f7f\u4eba\u9ad4\u5167\u7121\u6642\u4e0d\u5728\u7684\u81ea\u7531\u57fa\uff0c\u4e0d\u81f3\u5c0d\u6b63\u5e38\u7d30\u80de\u7684\u57fa\u56e0\u7522\u751f\u640d\u50b7\uff0c\u800c\u6e1b\u5c11\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u7684\u5f62\u6210\u3002\n\uff08\u516d\uff09\u6291\u5236\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u8a0a\u865f\u50b3\u905e: \u764c\u7d30\u80de\u7684\u6210\u9577\u9700\u8981\u751f\u9577\u6fc0\u7d20\uff0c\u751f\u9577\u6fc0\u7d20\u900f\u904e\u7d30\u80de\u5167\u7684\u8a0a\u865f\u50b3\u905e\u7cfb\u7d71\u52a0\u4ee5\u653e\u5927\uff0c\u4f7f\u5f97\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u4e0d\u65b7\u5206\u88c2\u589e\u751f\uff0c\u6291\u5236\u8a0a\u865f\u50b3\u905e\u7cfb\u7d71\uff0c\u5c31\u80fd\u5ef6\u5f8c\u764c\u5316\u904e\u7a0b\u4ee5\u53ca\u6291\u5236\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u7684\u5206\u88c2\u53ca\u6210\u9577\u3002\n\uff08\u4e03\uff09\u690d\u7269\u985e\u96cc\u6fc0\u7d20\u4e4b\u62ee\u6297\u4f5c\u7528: \u5177\u6709\u6e1b\u4f4e\u96c4\u6027\u6216\u96cc\u6027\u6fc0\u7d20\u5c0d\u7d30\u80de\u4e4b\u4f5c\u7528\uff0c\u56e0\u800c\u6291\u5236\u8207\u8377\u723e\u8499\u76f8\u95dc\u4e4b\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u7684\u6210\u9577\u3002\n\uff08\u516b\uff09\u81b3\u98df\u7e96\u7dad\u964d\u4f4e\u8178\u9053\u81f4\u764c\u7269\u5c0d\u4eba\u9ad4\u7684\u5f71\u97ff: \u56e0\u81b3\u98df\u7e96\u7dad\u4e0d\u88ab\u4eba\u9ad4\u6d88\u5316\u5438\u6536\uff0c\u53ef\u589e\u52a0\u7cde\u4fbf\u7684\u9ad4\u7a4d\u53ca\u91cd\u91cf\uff0c\u523a\u6fc0\u8178\u9053\u8815\u52d5\uff0c\u6392\u51fa\u9ad4\u5167\u6bd2\u7d20\uff1b\u540c\u6642\u56e0\u5176\u4e0d\u7522\u751f\u71b1\u91cf\u3001\u5bb9\u6613\u6709\u98fd\u8db3\u611f\uff0c\u6709\u52a9\u9ad4\u91cd\u63a7\u5236\uff0c\u53ef\u6709\u6548\u9810\u9632\u764c\u75c7\u3002\u53e6\u5916\uff0c\u81b3\u98df\u7e96\u7dad\u4ea6\u5177\u6709\u6e1b\u7de9\u98df\u7269\u7684\u6d88\u5316\u5438\u6536\u3001\u964d\u4f4e\u81bd\u56fa\u9187\u5438\u6536\u3001\u6e1b\u4f4e\u8840\u7ba1\u786c\u5316\u6a5f\u7387\u7b49\u529f\u80fd\u3002\n\n\u5e38\u898b\u7684\u690d\u5316\u7d20:\n\uff08\u4e00\uff09\u985e\u9ec3\u916e\u7d20\uff1a(1) \u82b1\u9752\u7d20\u3001\u524d\u82b1\u9752\u7d20\uff1b(2) \u5152\u8336\u7d20\uff1b(3) \u69f2\u76ae\u7d20\uff1b(4) \u6ab8\u6aac\u9ec3\u7d20\uff1b(5) \u82b8\u9999\u7d20\uff1b(6) \u82b9\u83dc\u7d20\u7b49\u3002\n\n\uff08\u4e8c\uff09\u985e\u80e1\u863f\u8514\u7d20\uff1a(1) \u03b2-\u80e1\u863f\u8514\u7d20\u3001\u03b2-\u96b1\u9ec3\u7d20\u3001\u03b1-\u80e1\u863f\u8514\u7d20\uff1b(2) Are saturated fat foods healthy or harmful? The science on saturated vs unsaturated fat foods, the controversies and the exceptions.\n\nSubscribe for more free nutrition and health tips: https://bit.ly/2toMJ9u\n\nConnect with me:\nFacebook: https://www.facebook.com/DrGilCarvalho/\nTwitter: https://twitter.com/NutritionMadeS3\nAnimations: Even Topland @toplandmedia\n\nSaturated vs unsaturated fat, let's make sense of fats!\n\nSaturated fat is concentrated in animal foods and some plant products like coconut oil while Unsaturated fat is concentrated in plants.\n\nSaturated fat raises cholesterol levels. But does it cause heart disease?\nClassical studies linked saturated fat and heart disease, so saturated fat was widely seen as a problem until a media storm a few years ago. Was saturated fat fine after all? \n\nIn 2 studies, people eating less saturated fat had just as much cardiovascular disease. So maybe saturated fat is not a factor?\n\nHarvard study: People who eat less saturated fat and more unsaturated fat instead have lower risk. Those who eat more whole grains instead also had lower risk. But refined grains were no better than saturated fat.\n\nBut maybe they eat less saturated fat, less cheese and meat and also smoke less and exercise more. How do we know the saturated fat has anything to do with them being healthier? A brand new study found people told to eat less  saturated fat have less cardiovascular disease. It wasn\u2019t clear which food replacements were best but less  saturated fat led to less risk. They found no harmful effects of reducing saturated fat.\nSaturated fat always raises emotions. I used to eat a lot more saturated fat and gradually adapted. Others might make a different decision.\n\nThis means favoring unprocessed plant foods which are low in saturated vs unsaturated fats. Fish is also a wise choice due to the balance of saturated vs unsaturated fat. Some types of saturated fat are worse than others. We covered dietary patterns low in saturated fat and high in unsaturated fats in previous videos.\n\nReferences:\nsaturated fat and serum cholesterol levels: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2125600/\nAHA Advisory: https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/full/10.1161/CIR.0000000000000510\n2 studies that generated the media storm:\nhttps://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24723079/\nhttps://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20071648/\nHarvard study:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4593072/\nrecent randomized trial (Cochrane): www.cochranelibrary.com/cdsr/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD011737.pub2/full\nstearic acid doesn't raise LDL-c: https://academic.oup.com/ajcn/article/77/5/1146/4689813\nchocolate and risk:\nhttps://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S089990071730206X\nhttps://www.mdpi.com/2072-6643/9/7/688\n\nDisclaimer: The contents of this video are for informational purposes only and are not intended to be medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment, nor to replace medical care. "en", "channelTitle": "MinuteEarth", "publishedAt": "2017-12-06T17:09:45Z", "description": "Thanks to 23andMe for sponsoring this video! http://www.23andme.com/minuteearth\nIf you live outside the US, click here: https://www.23andme.com/\n\nWhen we domesticate an animal species, their brains shrink and they freak out less.\n\nThanks also to our supporters on https://www.patreon.com/MinuteEarth\n\nAnd to our SPONSORS on YouTube.\n___________________________________________\n\nTo learn more, start your googling with these keywords: \nDomesticated animal: a species of animal bred by humans over generations to become nonreactive and gain characteristics suitable for life as a farm animal or pet\n\nTame animal: an individual animal raised in a way that it has become less dangerous and frightened of people\n\nFeral animal: an animal that escapes from captivity or domestication (& regains some similar & some different characteristics compared to its pre-domesticated state)\n\n\"Fight or flight\": an instinctive physiological response to a threatening situation that readies a creature to either to resist forcibly or escape\n\nLimbic system: the brain\u2019s \u201cpanic button\u201d - a system of nerves and networks near the bottom of the cortex that controls basic emotions (e.g. fear, pleasure, anger) and drives (e.g. hunger, sex, dominance)\n\nTelencephalon: the most developed and anterior part of the forebrain, consisting chiefly of the cerebral hemispheres, and the brain region that shrinks most in domesticated animals\n\nDomestication: a sustained multigenerational, mutualistic relationship in which one species (e.g. humans) assumes a significant degree of influence over the reproduction and care of another species (e.g. cows) in order to secure a more predictable supply of a resource of interest (e.g. milk/meat/traction), and through which the domesticated organisms gain advantage over individuals that remain outside this relationship (e.g. aurochs, which went extinct), thereby benefitting and often increasing the fitness of both species involved\n___________________________________________\n\nIf Face detection is a difficult task in image analysis which has each day more and more applications. In fact, the object \u201cface\u201d is hard to define because of its large variability, depending on the identity of the person, the lighting conditions, the psychological context of the person, etc.\n\nThe main challenge for detecting faces is to find a classifier which can discriminate faces from all other possible images.  The existing methods for face detection can be divided into image-based methods and feature-based methods. We have developed an intermediate system, using a Haar classifier-based algorithm and Curvelet based feature extraction which is capable of processing images rapidly with having good detection rates. The main idea in the Haar transformation algorithm is the discrete wavelet transformation of an image using haar coefficients to locate the maximum wavelet region which represents the face location. This improves both, the detection speed and the detection efficiency.  Whereas in split the total image into a small block (5X5) and apply the convolution process between each block and curvelet coefficient and find the features of all the image blocks.\n\nHAAR CLASSIFIER \nImage is converted to text format by using Matlab tool then apply haar construction to locate wavelet maximum region which is nothing but a face, after computation of the face location by using haar coefficients then haar reconstruction to retain the original image with located face regions. Here we are using the Modelsim tool for haar construction & haar reconstruction and again Matlab tool to get the output image.\n\nCURVELET TRANSFORM\nSelect image file\nRead image and convert pixel values\nSplit the total image into a small block (5X5)\nApply the convolution process between each block and curvelet coefficient data below here.\n\n[0.0039    0.0156    0.0234    0.0156    0.0039\n0.0156    0.0625    0.0938    0.0625    0.0156\n0.0234    0.0938    0.1406    0.0938    0.0234\n0.0156    0.0625    0.0938    0.0625    0.0156\n0.0039    0.0156    0.0234    0.0156    0.0039];\n\nFind the features of all the image blocks \n\nReference Paper-1: FPGA-Based Face Detection System Using Haar Classifiers\nAuthor\u2019s Name: Junguk Cho, Shahnam Mirzaei, Jason Oberg and metacognition is a measure of higher intelligence. What makes human different from other animals is that we have the ability to think about how we think. This means the ability to plan, set goals, and analyze. A lack of self awareness causes us to become self-destructive and to put ourselves in toxic or unhealthy situations. You do not want to be on auto-pilot or a robot do you? PubMed PMID: 30029599; PubMed Central PMCID:\nPMC6053833.", "tags": ["asma", "crise asm\u00e1tica", "vitamina d"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M35S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "52", "dislikeCount": "1", "viewCount": "328", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "3"}, "id": "meKL6svgJY0"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.011"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.011", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "When science & business talk \u2013 Intermediaries", "channelId": "UCy0B-Tk5xjnyQ0Q9bYJ03zA", "channelTitle": "Birkbeck, University of London", "publishedAt": "2018-06-11T09:19:14Z", "description": "Dr Muthu Da Silva talks about her research into the role that intermediaries play in the interaction between academics and business.\n\nRecorded as part of a workshop organised by the Birkbeck Centre for Innovation Management Research, centred around engagement between businesses and scientific centres.\n\nSince the financial crisis over a decade ago businesses in Europe remained prudent in its investment in innovation. Urgently needed for economic growth is that substantially larger funds are put towards innovative endeavours. This was the headline message of our 2017 Green Paper and its related workshop on Investment for Economic Recovery in Europe. The solution we hailed was more public investment, and, in particular, more public investment that takes the form of science-push policies, on the premise that private innovation related investments ought to follow. When publicly funded research centres generated innovations able to create new companies and even new industries - while these cases are certainly sporadic - they often had such an economic and social impact to justify the priority of public investment.\n\nFind out more here: http://www.bbk.ac.uk/innovation/\n\nFor more information on Dr Da Silva's research, please read:\n \nDe Silva, M., Rossi, F. (2018). The effect of firms\u2019 relational capabilities on knowledge acquisition and co-creation with universities. Technological Forecasting and Social Change. Forthcoming. Research Policy, 47 (1), 70-87\nDOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.respol.2017.09.011", "tags": ["research", "intermediaries", "value creation", "business", "University", "London", "Birkbeck", "BEI", "CIMR", "Muthu Da Silva", "co-creation"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en-GB"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT6M9S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "133", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "vVbxGJz4yko"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.011"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.003", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Diurnal feeding behavior of the American Eel Anguilla rostrata", "channelId": "UCOhUw_dukMNGv0c6BJRsacQ", "channelTitle": "Applied Ecology", "publishedAt": "2017-11-16T20:07:15Z", "description": "We documented American Eels (Anguilla rostrata) switching their typical nighttime, nonselective bottom feeding behavior to daytime, targeted selection on upstream-migrating goby postlarvae in Caribbean rivers (Puerto Rico). These are small, young fish (1-2 inches) with suction-cup-shaped fins (to climb rocks) that migrate from the ocean up the rivers once a month -- Eels love to snack on them! \n\nA note about this behavior was published in the journal Food Webs:\n\nEngman, A.C., J.R. Fischer, T.J. Kwak, and M.J. Walter. 2017. Diurnal feeding behavior of the American Eel Anguilla rostrata. Food Webs 13: 27-29.\n\nYou can view the paper here: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fooweb.2017.10.003", "tags": ["Anguilla rostrata", "American Eel", "Feeding behavior", "Food Webs", "Puerto Rico", "Goby"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M29S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "4", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "292", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "fXAg_TmU_vw"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.003"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.003", "items": [{"snippet": {"description": "Indexing predation / scavenging around shellfish reefs using standardised field assays (\u2018squidpops\u2019). \r\n\nThis video shows how we use \u2018squidpops\u2019 (a type of baited underwater camera system) to measure predation / scavenging rates and to identify consumers in field assays at restored shellfish reefs and control sites. \r\n\n\u2018Squidpops\u2019 are now a standard method for indexing relative predation rates of marine mesopredators, and have been used extensively for this purpose in coastal seascapes (Refs 1,2,3)  In essence, squidpops are baited under-water remote video stations (BRUVs), but have the major advantage that the same bait (and mostly also the same camera system) is used by scientists globally: this makes data directly comparable between locations and allows us to examine questions at large scales by a network of collaborators.  \r\n\n\u201cSquidpops\u201d consist of a single 1 cm^2 piece of dried squid mantle tethered to a 20 cm long bamboo stake using a 10 cm length of fishing line. Camera units comprised a 5 kg weight with a GoPro camera recording in high definition (1080p). The squidpop stake was fastened to the camera unit using a 15mm gauge PVC arm at a distance of 45 cm from the camera, so that the bait was visible at all times. \r\n\nDuring a recent study in the Noosa River Estuary (Australia) we deployed 384 squidpops at restored shellfish reefs and at matched control sites (Ref 3).  All deployments were made on bare substrate (i.e. not in seagrass meadows or mangrove forests). To maximise the probability of good visibility (water clarity), all assays were run within 2 hours either side of high tide (see also Ref 4).  Each baited camera recorded for one hour.  \r\n\nThe results demonstrate that predation is significantly higher at restored reefs and the presence and extent of nearby seagrass and mangroves suppresses consumption rates (i.e. reefs have more predation when located on bare sand; Ref 3).  \r\n\nREFERENCES\r\n1 - Duffy JE, Ziegler SL, Campbell JE, Bippus PM, Lefcheck JS (2015) Squidpops: a simple tool to crowdsource a global map of marine predation intensity. PLoS One 10, e0142994. \r\n\n2 - Rodemann JR, Brandl SJ (2017) Consumption pressure in coastal marine environments decreases with latitude and in artificial vs. natural habitats. Marine Ecology Progress Series 574, 167\u2013179. \r\n\n3 - Duncan CK, Gilby BL, Olds AD, Connolly RM, Ortodossi NL, Henderson CJ, and Schlacher TA (2019) Landscape context modifies the rate and distribution of predation around habitat restoration sites. Biological Conservation 237:97-104.  \r\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.biocon.2019.06.028\r\n\n4 \u2013 Gilby BL, Olds AD, Connolly RM, Yabsley NA, Maxwell PS, Tibbetts IR, Schoeman DS, Schlacher TA (2017) Umbrellas can work underwater: using threatened species as indicator and management surrogates can improve coastal conservation. Estuarine Coastal Shelf Science. 199: 132\u2013140. \r\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecss.2017.10.003 \r\n\nREEF RESTORATION KEYWORDS\r\n\nreefs, restoration, oysters, oyster reefs, habitat creation, Deixe seu like e ative as notifica\u00e7\u00f5es do canal!", "publishedAt": "2020-04-27T15:39:56Z", "title": "Revis\u00e3o Sistem\u00e1tica e Metan\u00e1lise", "channelId": "UC1TRSl9kf8Rgfo1NmvzAxGg", "channelTitle": "Dissertare Assessoria"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT43M3S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "56", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "NdD6e7rStQE"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.003"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.003", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "March 17, 2020: Exploring the Interactions between Water, Climate and Communication", "channelId": "UCIbosebk4Rh4LLEMKH_Q4Uw", "channelTitle": "Ohio State Environmental Professionals Network", "publishedAt": "2020-03-20T19:23:25Z", "description": "On Tuesday March 17, EPN hosted a Zoom Webinar-based program instead of our standard EPN in-person breakfast program. \n\nThis EPN Zoom Webinar-based program, co-hosted with the Water Management Association of Ohio (WMAO), the Ohio Water Resources Center, and TerrAqua (a multi-disciplinary student organization at Ohio State), occurred through an online format instead of our standard EPN in-person breakfast program. \n\nNumerous research agencies, including the U.S. Global Change Research Program, find that in the U.S. Midwest a variety of weather-related challenges are currently, and will increasingly, impact our local communities through such issues as extreme precipitation events and flooding, decreases in lake ice and snow cover, and increases in urban heat islands and drought nca2018.globalchange.gov/chapter/21/). These water-climate relationships are complex, dynamic and can be challenging to communicate. \n\nJoin this program as we learn about the interactions between the water cycle, changing weather patterns, and how to understand and communicate these issues in natural resource management. This program is in alignment with the March 22, 2020 World Water Day theme, which is \u201cabout water and climate change \u2013 and how the two are inextricably linked.\u201d (learn more at worldwaterday.org). Thanks to our colleagues at the Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center at Ohio State for helping to frame this program\u2019s agenda.\n\nThis program features: \n\nJoe Campbell, Ph.D. director, EPN, Hannah Comune, president, TerrAqua, and Eugene Braig, program director of aquatic ecosystems (SENR) and board president, WMAO, provide welcome remarks and program introduction\n\nBryan Mark, Ph.D., professor, Department of Geography and State Climatologist of Ohio, and Michael Durand, Ph.D., professor, School of Earth Sciences, present on the changing cryosphere in Earth's water cycle\n\nKim Channell, climatologist, Great Lakes Integrated Sciences and Assessments presents Climate Change in the Great Lakes \n\nRobyn Wilson, Ph.D., professor, SENR, presents Communicating climate change and promoting action in the Great Lakes\n\nAudience Q & A with Dr. Durand, Ms. Channell, and Dr. Wilson\n\nConcluding remarks by Jeff Sharp, Ph.D., director, School of Environment and Natural Resources, and Karina Peggau, education and outreach program coordinator, Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2H2M2S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "4", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "229", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "Z10HRRL2uLg"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.003"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.003", "items": [{"snippet": {"description": "A. Khalaf, M. Sybeldon, E. Sejdi\u0107, M. Akcakaya, \u201cA brain-computer interface based on functional transcranial Doppler ultrasound using wavelet transform and support vector machines,\u201d Journal of Neuroscience Methods, vol. 293, pp. 174-182, Jan. 2018.\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.jneumeth.2017.10.003\n\n\n\nABSTRACT:\n\nBACKGROUND: Functional transcranial Doppler (fTCD) is an ultrasound based neuroimaging technique used to assess neural activation that occurs during a cognitive task through measuring velocity of cerebral blood flow. NEW METHOD: The objective of this paper is to investigate the feasibility of a 2-class and 3-class real-time BCI based on blood flow velocity in left and right middle cerebral arteries in response to mental rotation and word generation tasks. Statistical features based on a five-level wavelet decomposition were extracted from the fTCD signals. The Wilcoxon test and support vector machines (SVM), with a linear kernel, were employed for feature reduction and classification. RESULTS: The experimental results showed that within approximately 3s of the onset of the cognitive task average accuracies of 80.29%, and 82.35% were obtained for the mental rotation versus resting state and the word generation versus resting state respectively. The mental rotation task versus word generation task achieved an average accuracy of 79.72% within 2.24s from the onset of the cognitive task. Furthermore, an average accuracy of 65.27% was obtained for the 3-class problem within 4.68s. COMPARISON WITH EXISTING METHODS: The results presented here provide significant improvement compared to the relevant fTCD-based systems presented in literature in terms of accuracy and speed. Specifically, the reported speed in this manuscript is at least 12 and 2.5 times faster than any existing binary and 3-class fTCD-based BCIs, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: These results show fTCD as a promising and viable candidate to be used towards developing a real-time BCI.\n\n\n#brain #datascience #machinelearning #supportvectormachines #neuroscience #braincomputerinterface #doppler #sonography", "publishedAt": "2020-03-05T20:49:44Z", "title": "A brain-computer interface based on transcranial Doppler using support vector machines", "channelId": "UCZTmNHUz63iphbhJc6d__JA", "channelTitle": "Ervin Sejdic"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M51S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "8", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "r0wF82eLotk"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.003"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.005", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "\u0411\u0440\u0438\u043d\u0442\u0435\u043b\u043b\u0438\u043a\u0441 \u0432\u044b\u0437\u044b\u0432\u0430\u0435\u0442 \u043a\u0435\u0442\u043e\u0430\u0446\u0438\u0434\u043e\u0437.", "channelId": "UCymH2k4lIlApC_9Hp2P3clA", "channelTitle": "\u041f\u0441\u0438\u0445\u0444\u0430\u0440\u043c \u0422\u0412", "publishedAt": "2018-11-29T16:31:58Z", "description": "\u041a\u0430\u043d\u0430\u043b \u041f\u0441\u0438\u0445\u0444\u0430\u0440\u043c \u0422\u0412 \u0438 \u0434.\u043c.\u043d. \u041c.\u042e. \u0414\u0440\u043e\u0431\u0438\u0436\u0435\u0432 \u0433\u043e\u0432\u043e\u0440\u044f\u0442 \u043e \u043a\u0435\u0442\u043e\u0430\u0446\u0438\u0434\u043e\u0437\u0435 - \u043d\u043e\u0432\u043e\u043c \u043f\u043e\u0431\u043e\u0447\u043d\u043e\u043c \u044d\u0444\u0444\u0435\u043a\u0442\u0435 \u0411\u0440\u0438\u043d\u0442\u0435\u043b\u043b\u0438\u043a\u0441\u0430, \u043a\u043e\u0442\u043e\u0440\u044b\u0439 \u0435\u0449\u0435 \u043d\u0435 \u043f\u043e\u043f\u0430\u043b \u0432 \u0435\u0433\u043e \u0438\u043d\u0441\u0442\u0440\u0443\u043a\u0446\u0438\u044e. \u041d\u0430\u0441\u043a\u043e\u043b\u044c\u043a\u043e \u044d\u0442\u043e \u043e\u043f\u0430\u0441\u043d\u043e? Sfakianakis", "publishedAt": "2018-01-16T06:22:55Z", "description": "Medicine by Alexandros G. Sfakianakis,Anapafseos 5 Agios Nikolaos 72100 Crete Greece,00302841026182,00306932607174,alsfakia@gmail.com,\r\nhttps://plus.google.com/communities/115462130054650919641?sqinv=VFJWaER0c2NCRl9ERzRjZWhxQmhzY09kVV84cjRn\r\n,\r\n,https://plus.google.com/u/0/+AlexandrosGSfakianakis\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA\r\n,\r\nhttps://twitter.com/g_orl?lang=el,\r\nhttps://www.instagram.com/alexandrossfakianakis/,\r\n\r\n\r\nArticle in Press\r\nEffect of Auditory-Perceptual Training With Natural Voice Anchors on Vocal Quality Evaluation\r\nPriscila Campos Martins dos Santos'Correspondence information about the author Priscila Campos Martins dos SantosEmail the author Priscila Campos Martins dos Santos, Maur\u00edlio Nunes Vieira, Jo\u00e3o Pedro Hallack Sans\u00e3o, Ana Cristina C\u00f4rtes Gama\r\nDOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jvoice.2017.10.020\r\nhideArticle Info\r\nPublication History\r\nPublished online: January 10, 2018\r\nAccepted: October 26, 2017\r\nAbstract\r\nFull Text\r\nImages\r\nReferences\r\nSummary\r\nPurpose\r\nTo analyze the effects of auditory-perceptual training with anchor stimuli of natural voices on inter-rater agreement during the assessment of vocal quality.\r\n\r\nStudy design\r\nThis is a quantitative nature study.\r\n\r\nMethods\r\nAn auditory-perceptual training site was developed consisting of Programming Interface A, an auditory training activity, and Programming Interface B, a control activity. Each interface had three stages: pre-training/pre-interval evaluation, training/interval, and post-training/post-interval evaluation. Two experienced evaluators classified 381 voices according to the GRBASI scale (G-grade, R-roughness, B-breathiness, A-asthenia, S-strain, I-instability). Voices were selected that received the same evaluation by both evaluators: 57 voices for evaluation and 56 for training were selected, with varying degrees of deviation across parameters. Fifteen inexperienced evaluators were then selected. In the pre-, post-training, pre-, and postinterval stages, evaluators listened to the voices and classified them via the GRBASI scale. In the stage interval evaluators read a text. In the stage training each parameter was trained separately. Evaluators analyzed the degrees of deviation of the GRBASI parameters based on anchor stimuli, and could only advance after correctly classifying the voices. To quantify inter-rater agreement and provide statistical analyses, the AC1 coefficient, confidence intervals, and percentage variation of agreement were employed.\r\n\r\nResults\r\nExcept for the asthenia parameter, decreased agreement was observed in the control condition. Improved agreement was observed with auditory training, but this improvement did not achieve statistical significance.\r\n\r\nConclusion\r\nTraining with natural voice anchors suggest an increased inter-rater agreement during perceptual voice analysis, potentially indicating that new internal references were established.\r\n\r\nKey Words:\r\nVoice, Voice quality, Dysphonia, Auditory perception, Voice training\n\r\n\r- video upload powered by https://www.TunesToTube.com", "tags": ["Training", "With", "Natural", "Voice", "Anchors"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M36S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "12", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "FY2YhUOm-6E"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.020"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.020", "items": [{"snippet": {"description": "Professor Jane Hill and Dr Sarah Scriven will discuss their recently published paper on incorporating connectivity into conservation planning for optimal representation.", "publishedAt": "2020-05-01T14:54:13Z", "title": "Ask the Author: Conservation Planning", "channelId": "UCWjjT5hXZdvzpJ6ys7XicrA", "channelTitle": "YESIatUoY"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT58M11S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "54", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "5iEiFd_v1KY"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.020"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.020", "items": [{"snippet": {"description": "S\u00e9timo semin\u00e1rio online promovido pela SBAFS para debater a elabora\u00e7\u00e3o do Guia de Atividade F\u00edsica para a Popula\u00e7\u00e3o Brasileira, realizado ao vivo no dia 22 de mar\u00e7o, \u00e0s 16 horas. Daniel Rodr\u00edguez Marconi. Director del Proyecto\nFlga. Giorgia Abd-del-Kader. Colaboradora\nFlgo. Felipe Henr\u00edquez. Colaborador\nFlga. Lisette Fuentes. Colaboradora\nFlgo Camilo Morales. Colaborador\nFlgo. Pablo Carrasco. Colaborador\nFlga. Claudia Bascu\u00f1\u00e1n. Colaboradora. \n\nEste proyecto fue financiado por la Direcci\u00f3n General de Docencia de la Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Temuco en un proyecto docente adjudicado en 2016. Los est\u00e1ndares de grabaci\u00f3n y edici\u00f3n fueron otorgados por la Direcci\u00f3n de Tecnolog\u00edas Educativas de la Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Temuco. \nEl proyecto est\u00e1 abierto a nuevas colaboraciones a medida que sea necesario actualizar la evidencia cient\u00edfica existente, por lo que se admiten futuras colaboraciones para seguir potenciando la Fonoaudiolog\u00eda en Iberoam\u00e9rica. Daniel Rodr\u00edguez Marconi. Director del Proyecto\nFlga. Giorgia Abd-del-Kader. Colaboradora\nFlgo. Felipe Henr\u00edquez. Colaborador\nFlga. Lisette Fuentes. Colaboradora\nFlgo Camilo Morales. Colaborador\nFlgo. Pablo Carrasco. Colaborador\nFlga. Claudia Bascu\u00f1\u00e1n. Colaboradora. \n\nEste proyecto fue financiado por la Direcci\u00f3n General de Docencia de la Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Temuco en un proyecto docente adjudicado en 2016. Los est\u00e1ndares de grabaci\u00f3n y edici\u00f3n fueron otorgados por la Direcci\u00f3n de Tecnolog\u00edas Educativas de la Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Temuco. \nEl proyecto est\u00e1 abierto a nuevas colaboraciones a medida que sea necesario actualizar la evidencia cient\u00edfica existente, por lo que se admiten futuras colaboraciones para seguir potenciando la Fonoaudiolog\u00eda en Iberoam\u00e9rica. At that time, the internal organs had been identified and named. However, the spleen was mistakenly thought to be the major digestive organ, associated with the stomach, while the pancreas was overlooked. But in fact, it is the pancreas that serves this function, and the spleen plays no part in digestion. Unfortunately, this mistake has been perpetuated to today, and in Chinese Medicine, whenever the pancreas is referred to, it is known as the spleen. Hopefully, this mistake will soon be corrected in textbooks, and in Chinese Medicine clinics. This includes how conditions such as migraines, stress and lung-related conditions are produced, and how acupuncture treats these by correcting malfunctions in the related organs.\n\nThis channel avoids the mumbo jumbo that is usually used to explain acupuncture. Instead, terms and concepts are used that are familiar to Westerners. The explanations rely on the intelligent tissue theory, which is a new explanation for acupuncture, developed over many years by an experienced Chinese Medicine acupuncturist (myself) who is also trained in a range of sciences.\n\nFOR FURTHER INFORMATION\nThe following is an inexpensive book that is aimed at the general reader and gives a good overview of acupuncture, what it can treat and how it works:\nhttp://www.curiouspages.com/ae\nSee also, my Amazon pages:\nhttps://www.amazon.com/Fletcher-Kovich/e/B01GHOPYEY/\nOr:\nhttps://www.amazon.co.uk/Fletcher-Kovich/e/B01GHOPYEY/\n\nThe \u201cresonance\u201d between an organ and its meridian locations, is explained by the intelligent tissue theory. I will cover this is greater detail in other videos; but for those wanting the full explanation, please see Chapters 17-20 in the following book:\nhttp://www.curiouspages.com/atac/\n\nChinese acupuncturists often use the term \u201cchi\u201d. In another video I will explain how this term came about, and how it relates to the intelligent tissue theory.\n\nWHAT ARE THE \u201cMERIDIANS\u201d?\nFor more information on this, please see the following:\nhttps://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2005290118300037\nAnd Chapters 17 and 19 in the following book:\nhttp://www.curiouspages.com/atac/\n\nTHE CONFUSION BETWEEN THE PANCREAS AND SPLEEN IN CHINESE MEDICINE\nThe earliest surviving scripts that record the main Chinese Medicine knowledge, date back to around 200 BC. At that time, the internal organs had been identified and named. However, the spleen was mistakenly thought to be the major digestive organ, associated with the stomach, while the pancreas was overlooked. But in fact, it is the pancreas that serves this function, and the spleen plays no part in digestion. Unfortunately, this mistake has been perpetuated to today, and in Chinese Medicine, whenever the pancreas is referred to, it is known as the spleen. Hopefully, this mistake will soon be corrected in textbooks, and in Chinese Medicine clinics. For a fuller discussion, see pages 61-63 in the following book:\nhttp://www.curiouspages.com/atac/\n\nFor further information on the Chinese Medicine pulses and how they are produced, please see Chapter 15, pages 299-305, in the following book:\nhttp://www.curiouspages.com/atac/\n\nMY PUBLISHED PAPERS ON ACUPUNCTURE AND THE INTELLIGENT TISSUE THEORY, WHICH CAN ALL BE READ IN FULL, FREE OF CHARGE:\nKovich F.
