Michigan Engineering is home to 12 highly-ranked departments, and its research budget is among the largest of any public university. \nhttp://engin.umich.edu/\n\n-----\nMore on the video:\nIn many areas, centralized drinking water systems are used. Unfortunately, these systems can pose issues if a natural disaster or some phenomena turns the systems offline. They can also have a small target, as the centralized water system in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia only serves less than 10% of the city. By using a combination of decentralized and centralized systems, we can find ways to solve this issue and provide a sustainable system to the US and developing countries. \n\nNancy Love, Professor of Civil and Environmental Engineering at the University of Michigan, and Geremew Sahilu Gerbrie, Assistant Professor of Civil and Environmental Engineering at Addis Ababa University are developing a curriculum to train students to develop decentralized water systems and manage sewage at the neighborhood level. \n\nCheck out Love\u2019s Group: https://envbiotech.engin.umich.edu/profile/love/\n\nRead the paper: \u201cAn automated toolchain for the data-driven and dynamical modeling of combined sewer systems,\u201d Water Research (2017).\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.watres.2017.08.065\n\nFollow Michigan Engineering:\nTwitter: https://twitter.com/umengineering\nFacebook: https://facebook.com/michigan.engineering\nInstagram: https://instagram.com/michiganengineering\n\nContact Michigan Engineering:\nhttps://engin.umich.edu/about/contact/", "tags": ["Michigan Engineering", "University of Michigan", "University of Michigan Engineering", "University of Michigan College of Engineering", "academics", "water research", "water problems", "civil engineering", "environmental engineering", "Ethiopia", "drinking water", "sewer systems", "environment", "environmental issues"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M50S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "16", "dislikeCount": "1", "viewCount": "862", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "2"}, "id": "bsIZwndAHy0"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.08.065"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.020", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "\u00bfQu\u00e9 planea hacer China en el lado oscuro de la Luna?", "channelId": "UCaVPhFg-Ax873wvhbNitsrQ", "channelTitle": "El Robot de Plat\u00f3n", "publishedAt": "2019-01-04T19:31:49Z", "description": "China ha aterrizado en el lado oscuro de la Luna \u00bfqu\u00e9 har\u00e1 all\u00ed? Computations from \"Optimal perturbations for nonlinear systems using graph-based optimal transport: Grover,P. and Elamvazhuthi, K., \n\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.cnsns.2017.09.020\n\nFor each time step t, the video shows the sequence (k=1 to 10) of optimal perturbations computed via continuous pseudo-time Monge-Kantorovich flow on graphs, followed by action of Perron-Frobenius operator. This sequence is repeated over multiple time-steps.\n\nwww.piyushgrover.org", "tags": ["optimal transport", "mixing", "perron-frobenius", "double gyre"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT36S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "207", "favoriteCount": "0"}, "id": "ozsx3xeUrCQ"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.020"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.001", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "New Treatment Causes Cancer to Self Destruct - scitechdaily.com", "channelId": "UCSjmhIUju8bG4uWznPpHqCw", "channelTitle": "EnergyScitechCom", "publishedAt": "2017-10-10T18:11:32Z", "description": "This image depicts the structure of the BAX protein (purple). The activator compound BTSA1 (orange) has bound to the active site of BAX (green), changing the shape of the BAX molecule at several points (shown in yellow, magenta and cyan). BAX, once in its final activated form, can home in on mitochondria and puncture their outer membranes, triggering apoptosis (cell death). Credit: Albert Einstein College of Medicine\n\nA team of researchers at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine reveals the first compound that directly makes cancer cells commit suicide while sparing healthy cells. The new treatment approach was directed against acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells but may also have potential for attacking other types of cancers.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re hopeful that the targeted compounds we\u2019re developing will prove more effective than current anti-cancer therapies by directly causing cancer cells to self-destruct,\u201d says Evripidis Gavathiotis, Ph.D., associate professor of biochemistry and of medicine and senior author of the study. \u201cIdeally, our compounds would be combined with other treatments to kill cancer cells faster and more efficiently\u2013and with fewer adverse effects, which are an all-too-common problem with standard chemotherapies.\u201d\n\nAML accounts for nearly one-third of all new leukemia cases and kills more than 10,000 Americans each year. The survival rate for patients has remained at about 30 percent for several decades, so better treatments are urgently needed.\n\nThe newly discovered compound combats cancer by triggering apoptosis\u2013an important process that rids the body of unwanted or malfunctioning cells. Apoptosis trims excess tissue during embryonic development, for example, and some chemotherapy drugs indirectly induce apoptosis by damaging DNA in cancer cells.\n\nApoptosis occurs when BAX\u2013the \u201cexecutioner protein\u201d in cells\u2013is activated by \u201cpro-apoptotic\u201d proteins in the cell. Once activated, BAX molecules home in on and punch lethal holes in mitochondria, the parts of cells that produce energy. But all too often, cancer cells manage to prevent BAX from killing them. They ensure their survival by producing copious amounts of \u201canti-apoptotic\u201d proteins that suppress BAX and the proteins that activate it.\n\n\u201cOur novel compound revives suppressed BAX molecules in cancer cells by binding with high affinity to BAX\u2019s activation site,\u201d says Dr. Gavathiotis. \u201cBAX can then swing into action, killing cancer cells while leaving healthy cells unscathed.\u201d\n\nDr. Gavathiotis was the lead author of a 2008 paper in Nature that first described the structure and shape of BAX\u2019s activation site. He has since looked for small molecules that can activate BAX strongly enough to overcome cancer cells\u2019 resistance to apoptosis. His team initially used computers to screen more than one million compounds to reveal those with BAX-binding potential. The most promising 500 compounds\u2013many of them newly synthesized by Dr. Gavathiotis\u2019 team\u2013were then evaluated in the laboratory.\n\n\u201cA compound dubbed BTSA1 (short for BAX Trigger Site Activator 1) proved to be the most potent BAX activator, causing rapid and extensive apoptosis when added to several different human AML cell lines,\u201d says lead author Denis Reyna, M.S., a doctoral student in Dr. Gavathiotis\u2019 lab. The researchers next tested BTSA1 in blood samples from patients with high-risk AML. Strikingly, BTSA1 induced apoptosis in the patients\u2019 AML cells but did not affect patients\u2019 healthy blood-forming stem cells.\n\nFinally, the researchers generated animal models of AML by grafting human AML cells into mice. BTSA1 was given to half the AML mice while the other half served as controls. On average, the BTSA1-treated mice survived significantly longer (55 days) than the control mice (40 days), with 43 percent of BTSA1-treated AML mice alive after 60 days and showing no signs of AML.\n\nImportantly, the mice treated with BTSA1 showed no evidence of toxicity. \u201cBTSA1 activates BAX and causes apoptosis in AML cells while sparing healthy cells and tissues\u2013probably because the cancer cells are primed for apoptosis,\u201d says Dr. Gavathiotis. He notes that his study found that AML cells from patients contained significantly higher BAX levels compared with normal blood cells from healthy people. \u201cWith more BAX available in AML cells,\u201d he explained, \u201ceven low BTSA1 doses will trigger enough BAX activation to cause apoptotic death, while sparing healthy cells that contain low levels of BAX or none at all.\u201d\n\nPlans call for Dr. Gavathiotis and his team to see whether BTSA1 will show similar effectiveness when tested on animal models of other types of cancer.\n\nPublication: Denis E. Reyna, et al., \u201cDirect Activation of BAX by BTSA1 Overcomes Apoptosis Resistance in Acute Myeloid Leukemia,\u201d Cancer Cell, 2017; doi:10.1016/j.ccell.2017.09.001\n\nSource: Albert Einstein DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jfbs.2017.09.001\n \nAvailable at: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1877858517300578\n\nThis article reviews research on women\u2019s involvement in family firms according to a drivers-behaviors-outcomes framework. Through a systematic review, we analyze and organize the content of 87 academic articles according to the type of involvement of women in family business, i.e. entrepreneurial entry, succession, career dynamics, and presence in family firms. We identify the drivers and outcomes of women\u2019s involvement in family firms at the firm, family, and individual level of analysis, as well as the contextual factors that may influence the aforementioned elements. "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.021", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Denti Dritti Subito: AcceleDent", "channelId": "UCHtexlGQYnkYPeltvUc7fjQ", "channelTitle": "ortodonzia- torino", "publishedAt": "2019-02-23T21:35:01Z", "description": "Fai subito il TEST:\nhttps://ortodonzia-torino.it/iscriviti\n\nQuarta puntata della mini serie \"Denti Dritti Subito\", che ho pensato per indagare insieme sulle tecniche (e le bufale) per avere i denti dritti in poco tempo.\n\n\nAcceledent (Orthoaccel Technology) e VPro5 (Propel) sono dispositivi progettati per velocizzare il trattamento con l\u2019apparecchio.\n\n\u00c9 facile entusiasmarsi quando nuove tecnologie vengono incontro al nostro desiderio di avere i denti dritti in poco tempo.\n\nMi riferisco ad Acceledent, a VPro5 di Propel e altri simili, dispositivi vibranti che si tengono tra i denti per 20 minuti al giorno.\n\n***Funzionano davvero?\n\nSecondo i produttori la vibrazione stimola il metabolismo, e i denti si spostano pi\u00f9 rapidamente, e senza dolore.\n\nLe recensioni dei pazienti sul web sono positive, ma si tratta di impressioni personali, che possono essere influenzate da tanti fattori (in perfetta buona fede)\n\nLe opinioni dei colleghi dentisti sono discordanti.\n\n\n***Ci possiamo fidare di questa promessa?\n\nLa letteratura scientifica non \u00e8 ottimista e la maggior parte delle ricerche cliniche non ha rilevato vantaggi nell\u2019uso di questi dispositivi.\n\nTi cito un articolo uscito sull'American Journal of Orthodontics portato avanti da 3 universit\u00e0 inglesi, in cui hanno preso 81 pazienti, a 29 (circa \u2153) hanno consegnato il dispositivo, a 25 uno finto tipo placebo e ai restanti non hanno dato nulla.\n\nN\u00e8 i dentisti n\u00e8 i ricercatori, che hanno fatto le misurazioni, sapevano chi aveva il dispositivo e chi no.\n\nIn questo modo i risultati non sono stati influenzati dalle opinioni personali. E cosa hanno visto? Che non ci sono state differenze tra i pazienti.\n\nEcco il link se sei interessato (l'articolo completo \u00e8 a pagamento, il \"riassunto\" \u00e9 gratis) \n\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.ajodo.2017.10.021\n\n\nTuttavia ci sono esperimenti in laboratorio che hanno dato risultati positivi, ma sembra che ci sia un paradosso con il processo di infiammazione, che \u00e8 alla base dello spostamento ortodontico dei denti.\n\nQui il link all'articolo https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0196540\n(\u00e8 un po' tecnico)\n\nInfatti, le vibrazioni esaltano questo fenomeno ma solo se \u00e8 gi\u00e0 in atto, mentre lo inibiscono se non \u00e8 ancora presente.\n\nNella prima ricerca che ho citato, per\u00f2, hanno consegnato il dispositivo da subito, quando ancora l\u2019apparecchio non aveva innescato questo processo.\n\n***Conclusioni?\n\nPenso che sia prematuro giudicare questa tecnologia, che ha delle potenzialit\u00e0, ma ci sono ancora delle cose da chiarire e aspettiamo i risultati delle prossime ricerche.\n\n\nChiss\u00e0, magari tra qualche anno dovr\u00f2 modificare il test che ho preparato per prevedere la durata del trattamento con l\u2019apparecchio fisso, che puoi trovare su\n\nhttps:www.ortodonzia-torino.it/iscriviti e che ti arriver\u00e0 via email.\n\nE\u2019 un gioco e non sostituisce una diagnosi ma ci azzecca abbastanza.\n\n*******\nAutore:\nDr.Tito Mattia Bordino\nStudio Dentistico di Ortodonzia\nC.so Re Umberto 77\nTorino\n\nSe vuoi prenotare una visita:\n0115805965\n\nSe vuoi \uc790\uc8fc \uad8c\uc7a5\ub429\ub2c8\ub2e4. \uc6b4\ub3d9\uc740 \ud608\uc555\uc744 \ub0ae\ucd94\ub294\ub370\uc694, \uc77c\uba85 Post-exercise hypotension (PEH) \uc6b4\ub3d9 \ud6c4 \uc99d\uba85\ub418\uc5b4 \uc654\uc2b5\ub2c8\ub2e4. \uc6e8\uc774\ud2b8 \ud558\uc2dc\ub294 \ubd84\ub4e4\uc5d0\uac8c \ud38c\ud551\uc744 \uc900\ub2e4\uace0 \ud574\uc11c \uc0b0\ud654\uc9c8\uc18c-nitric \uc2dd\uc774\uc9c8\uc0b0\uc5fc\uc774 \uc0b0\ud654\uc9c8\uc18c-no\ub85c \ubc14\ub00c\uae30 \ub54c\ubb38\uc5d0 \ud608\uc555\uc5d0 \ub3c4\uc6c0\uc744 \uc8fc\uace0 \uc6b4\ub3d9 \uc2dc \ud38c\ud551\uacfc \uc218\ucd95\uae30 \ud608\uc555\uc774 \ub5a8\uc5b4\uc9c0\ub294 \uac83 \ubfd0\ub9cc\uc774 \uc544\ub2c8\ub77c \uc6b4\ub3d9 \uc911\uc5d0 \uadfc\uc721\uc5d0 \uc0b0\uc18c\uc640 \uc601\uc591\uc18c\uac00 \uc798 \uacf5\uae09\ub418\uc5b4 \uc6b4\ub3d9 \uc131\ub2a5\uc774 \ud5a5\uc0c1\ub41c\ub2e4\ub294 \uac83\uc740 \uc798 \uc54c\ub824\uc838 \uc788\uc8e0! \n\nNitric Oxide-\uc0b0\ud654\uc9c8\uc18c\ub294 1998\ub144 \ub178\ubca8\uc0c1 \uc218\uc0c1\uc790\ub4e4\uc5d0 \uc758\ud574\uc11c \uc8fc\ubaa9\ubc1b\uae30 \uc2dc\uc791\ud588\ub294\ub370\uc694 \uc774\ub54c\uc57c \ube44\ub85c\uc11c \uc0b0\ud654\uc9c8\uc18c\uac00 \uc2ec\ud608\uad00\uacc4\uc758 \ud575\uc2ec \ubd84\uc790\uc774\uba70 \ud608\uc555\uc744 \uc870\uc808\ud558\uace0 \ud608\uad00\uc744 \uac74\uac15\ud558\uac8c \uc720\uc9c0\ud558\ub294\ub370 \ub3c4\uc6c0\uc774 \ub41c\ub2e4\ub294 \uac83\uc744 \ubc1c\uacac\ud574 \ub0c8\uc2b5\ub2c8\ub2e4.\n\n\uadf8\ub7ec\uba74 NO(\uc0b0\ud654\uc9c8\uc18c)\uc640 \uad6c\uac15 \ubc15\ud14c\ub9ac\uc544, \ud56d\uade0 \uac00\uae00 \uc774 \uc774\uc57c\uae30\ub97c \uc65c \ud588\ub290\ub0d0! \uc5f0\uad6c\ub4e4\uc744 \ubcf4\uaca0\uc2b5\ub2c8\ub2e4.\n\n\ud608\uc555\uc744 \ub0ae\ucd94\ub294 \ud6a8\uacfc\ub97c \ubcf4\uae30 \uc704\ud574\uc11c \uc6b4\ub3d9\uc744 \ud55c\ub2e4\uba74 \uad6c\uac15 \uac00\uae00, \uc785\uc548 \ubc15\ud14c\ub9ac\uc544\ub97c \uc5c6\uc560\uae30 Radical Biology and Medicine \ud559\uc220\uc9c0\uc5d0 \uc6b4\ub3d9 \ud6c4 \ud608\uc555 \uac15\ud558\ub97c \uc720\ubc1c\ud558\ub294 \uc694\uc778\uc774 \ubb34\uc5c7\uc778\uc9c0\ub97c \uc9c8\uc0b0\uc5fc(nitrate, No3)\uc744 \uc544\uc9c8\uc0b0\uc5fc(nitrite, No2)\uc73c\ub85c \ubcc0\ud658(convert)\uc2dc\ud0a4\ub294\ub370 \uc544\uc9c8\uc0b0\uc5fc\uc740 \uc6b0\ub9ac \uccb4\ub0b4 \ubcf4\uace0\uc600\uc2b5\ub2c8\ub2e4. \n\uc5f0\uad6c\uc9c4\ub4e4\uc740 \ucc38\uac00\uc790\ub4e4\uc5d0\uac8c \ud56d\uade0 \uac00\uae00 anti bacterial mouthwash \uadf8\ub8f9\uacfc \ubc18\uba74 \ud56d\uade0 \uc138\uc815\uc81c\ub85c \ud5f9\uad70 \ucc38\uc5ec\uc790\uc758 \uacbd\uc6b0 2.0mmHg\uac00 \uac10\uc18c\ud588\uc2b5\ub2c8\ub2e4. \n\n\uacb0\uacfc\uc801\uc73c\ub85c S\u00f8ndergaard", "publishedAt": "2017-10-11T03:34:55Z", "description": "Tagging of Endogenous RAD21 with an AuxinInducible Degron Allows for Rapid, Near Complete Cohesin Loss. A In HCT116RAD21mAC cells, both RAD21 alleles are tagged with auxininducible degrons and an mClover reporter, and the OsTIR1 gene is integrated at the AAVS1 locus. Auxin treatment leads to proteasomal degradation of RAD21. B Live cell imaging after Hoechst 33342 staining to label nuclei. Nuclear mClover fluorescence corresponding to tagged RAD21 was lost after 1 hr of auxin treatment. C SMC1 and CTCF ChIPseq signal with and without auxin treatment. After RAD21 degradation, the cohesin complex no longer binds to chromatin. CTCF binding is unaffected. Credit Cell. DOI 10.1016j.cell.2017.09.026 A multiinstitutional team spanning Baylor College of Medicine, Rice University, Stanford University and the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard has created the first highresolution 4D map of genome folding, tracking an entire human genome as it folds over time. The report, which may lead to new ways of understanding genetic diseases, appears on the cover of Cell. Making Connections For decades, researchers have suspected that when a human cell responds to a stimulus, DNA elements that lie far apart in the genome quickly find one another, forming loops along the chromosome. By rearranging these DNA elements in space, the cell is able to change which genes are active. In 2014, the same team of scientists showed it was possible to map these loops. But the first maps were static, without the ability to watch the loops change. It was unclear whether, in the crowded space of the nucleus, DNA elements could find each other fast enough to control cellular responses. Before, we could make maps of how the genome folded when it was in a particular state, but the problem with a static picture is that if nothing ev...\r\nThank for watching, Please Like Share And SUBSCRIBE!!!", "tags": ["Researchers map human", "map human genome", "human genome in", "genome in 4d", "in 4d as", "4d as it", "Researchers map", "map human", "human genome", "genome in", "in 4d", "4d as", "as it"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT5M50S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "50", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "OPPKo42pN9U"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.026"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.014", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Rompecabezas - Divulgaci\u00f3n cient\u00edfica - Sin\u00f3nimos", "channelId": "UC65Z1XNC-RY_W9RzLCqX24g", "defaultLanguage": "es-419", "channelTitle": "Laboratorio de psicolog\u00eda UCC", "publishedAt": "2019-04-13T00:43:06Z", "description": "Rese\u00f1a del art\u00edculo de investigaci\u00f3n \"When having two names facilitates lexical selection: Similar results in the picture-word task from translation distractors in bilinguals and synonym distractors in monolinguals\" publicado en la revista Cognition por Alexandra S.Dylman y Christopher Barry en el a\u00f1o 2018. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cognition.2017.09.014\nProducci\u00f3n: Onda Digital Universitaria (http://ondadigitalu.com/) y Centro de Habilidades Cognitivas. The numeric sense of genetic risk does not always correspond to their understanding of risk information. Instead, research participants tend to understand genetic risk as a binary concept: you either are at risk, or you are not.\n\nBinary thinking may help patients make sense of complex information, enabling them to make important decisions about their future. The authors suggest tailoring the discussion of genetic risk to participants\u2019 own understanding, to optimize the communication between participants and counselors and to help research participants make difficult decisions about their lives.\n\nRisk information is complex & difficult to understand. It tells us how likely we are to develop disease. We found that research participants think of risk as something binary. Either it will happen to you, or it won't. But genetic tests do not give YES or NO answers. When they learn about their risk, it changes how they think about their past, present & future. Risk statistics are difficult to understand. Binary thinking could be a coping mechanism to help them make decisions. People need proper counseling that fits their own understanding. To help them make decisions about their future. \n\nMind the Risk is a six year international network collaboration with scientists and researchers from Uppsala, Birmingham, G\u00f6ttingen, Manchester, Milano and Stockholm funded by Riksbankens Jubileumsfond (The Swedish Foundation for Humanities and Social Sciences)", "tags": ["genetic counselling", "Riksbankens Jubileumsfond", "Mind the Risk", "Centrum f\u00f6r forsknings- och bioetik", "Centre for Research Ethics & Bioethics", "Uppsala universitet", "Uppsala University", "dna", "genetics", "genetic", "risk information", "genetic risk", "genetic risk information"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M47S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "70", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "xk-hU6SRU1Q"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.009"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.009", "items": [{"snippet": {"description": "Domenica 22 aprile - Sessioni plenarie\nIV Sessione - Update nella valutazione, interpretazione e terapia dell\u2019occhio secco \nModeratori: Luigi Lupelli e Francesco Sala\n\nIl drop out nel 2017 e nuovi materiale per la gestione del DCL da dry eye, Pietro Gheller", "publishedAt": "2018-10-04T13:07:19Z", "title": "IBZ - Il drop out nel 2017 e nuovi materiale per la gestione del DCL da dry eye, Pietro Gheller", "channelId": "UCk6pAfA79uyC0Ox_9liccHA", "channelTitle": "Istituto Benigno Zaccagnini IBZ, Bologna"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT11M10S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "30", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "63ARnfu6Brg"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.009"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.036", "items": [{"snippet": {"description": "", "publishedAt": "2020-06-06T21:30:06Z", "title": "Defensa TFM. Then the coverslip is placed on a slide with the sealing vaseline border to prevent the preparation from drying out too quickly. The preparation is then placed on the microscope with the coverslip up. Observation starts immediately.\n\nContact: Dr. Alexander Kudryavtsev, St-Petersburg State University (alexander.kudryavtsev@spbu.ru)", "tags": ["Amoebozoa", "Discosea", "Vannellida", "Ripella", "Ripella tribonemae", "freshwater amoeba", "differential interference contrast", "light microscopy"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M4S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "46", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "_OcQ0t9Xt3k"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.003"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.003", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Can exercise really benefit your mental health? \ud83e\udd14", "channelId": "UCPxk3Uz4BSnTV8316fzkH_w", "channelTitle": "Seribu Tujuan", "publishedAt": "2020-04-12T10:00:02Z", "description": "This week in Seribu Tujuan Explains (tries), we talk about the psychological and physiological benefits of exercise. \n\n1:49 - Part 1: \u201cJust exercise!\u201d\n3:06 - Part 2: How has exercise benefitted your mental health?\n6:26 - Part 3: What does exercise do to your brain?\n10:21 - Part 4: Building a habit \n\nWe realise that many of us are currently impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Springer Science and Business Media LLC. http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10943-016-0211-1.", "publishedAt": "2020-08-15T23:28:20Z", "title": "Os 4 pilares da sa\u00fade", "channelId": "UCm8Zbfgoe9ljcJ246BG_GOw", "channelTitle": "Lucas Simionato Carra"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT12M7S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "3", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "48", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "2"}, "id": "yn5WxzhtYY0"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.003"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.09.013", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Achillies Tendon  US, Dynamic Achilles Rupture.  JETem 2019", "channelId": "UC2xvpSRrxTKOzRBPG6cIFBw", "channelTitle": "JETem", "publishedAt": "2019-10-04T18:27:34Z", "description": "Rudy C, et al. Ultrasonographic Findings of Acute Achilles Tendon Rupture. JETem 2019. 4(4):V14-16. https://doi.org/10.21980/J8063S\n\nHistory of present illness:  \nA 47-year-old male presents with acute right Achilles tendon (AT) pain.  When he was vaulting off a diving board, he felt a snapping sensation in his right lower extremity, with a sudden onset pain and associated swelling.\n\nSignificant findings: \nThe ultrasound video clip shows a longitudinal view of the AT during a dynamic exam. \nWhile the patient\u2019s foot is gently passively dorsi/plantar flexed, the video demonstrates first a normal Achilles tendon (from the unaffected extremity) without disruption (highlighted by a yellow bracket on screen left).  Then it shows an abnormal tendon (the patient\u2019s affected side) with disruption of the typical linear tendon fibers (red arrow identifies area of rupture). Dynamic testing shows the movement of the distal stump of the AT is evident adjacent to hypoechoic fluid that is reactive edema or blood from the acute rupture.  \n\nDiscussion: \nAchilles tendon rupture identified in the emergency department is often made by history and physical exam alone; however, up to 20% of ruptures are missed during the hyperacute phase.    Delayed diagnosis and subsequent treatment delay can lead to a permanently discontinuous or lengthened tendon; patients experience poorer functional performance and strength. Additionally, surgical repair is more complicated with a higher risk of complications. \n\nAccurate identification and referral can prevent significant functional morbidity. To facilitate diagnosis, point of care ultrasound (POCUS) is a helpful adjunctive tool to confirm the suspected diagnosis.  Ultrasound has been found to be 79%-100% sensitive for this injury. Evaluate the AT systematically in two planes: a superior-inferior direction (longitudinal) and medial-lateral (axial) through the full length and width of the tendon through the myotendinous junction.  In a healthy tendon, the fibers are oriented in a fibrillar linear and regular pattern.  In the disrupted tendon, the fibers may appear thickened, wavy, or as an abrupt edge of a completely disrupted tendon stump with/without retraction.  Secondary signs of AT tear include hypoechogenic areas within or deep to the tendon. A common pitfall in the evaluation of a tendon is to mistake anisotropy for AT tearing or rupture.  Anisotropy is the natural tendency for a structure to have apparent changing density as the angle of sound waves directed at the tissue changes.  The tendon will appear to change from a hyperechoic to hypoechoic structure as the ultrasound transducer is fanned. This can lead to the common pitfall that a hypoechoic structure appears torn.  Fanning and toeing the probe to evaluate for anisotropy and looking for secondary signs of rupture can help distinguish between a ruptured tendon and a normal healthy tendon. Additionally, gentle dynamic active or passive movement placing the tendon under slight tension can help distinguish the presence of tear or rupture.  A subtle tear can be exaggerated with gentle dorsiflexion of the foot as the tendon is stretched to length. If a full thickness tear is present, the distal stump will move across the screen as seen in the associated video.  \n\nThe patient was diagnosed with a full thickness AT rupture. The patient's foot was braced in an equine position, and the patient was given close outpatient orthopedic follow-up.  Surgical therapy was selected and the patient is recovering well.\n\nReferences: \n1. Hartgerink P, Fessell D, Jacobson J, van Holsbeeck M. Full- versus partial-thickness achilles tendon tears: sonographic accurancy and characterization in 26 cases with surgical correlation. Radiology. 2001;220(2):406-412.\n2. BMJ. 2015;351:h4722. doi: 10.1136/bmj.h4722.\n4. Robinson P. Sonography of common tendon injuries.  Am J Roentgenol. 2009;193(3):607-618. doi: 10.2214/AJR.09.2808.\n5. Dams OC, Reininga IH, Gielen JL, van den Akker-Scheek I, Zwerver J. Imaging modalities in the diagnosis and monitoring of Achilles tendon ruptures: a systematic review. Injury. 2017;48(11):2383-2399. doi: 10.1016/j.injury.2017.09.013.\n6. Adhikari S, Marx J, Crum T. Point-of-care ultrasound diagnosis of acute Achilles tendon rupture in the ED. Am J Emerg Med. 2012;30(4):634 e633-634. doi: 10.1016/j.ajem.2011.01.029.\n7. Garcia T, Hornof WJ, Insana MF. On the ultrasonic properties of tendon. Ultrasound Med Biol. 2003;29(12):1787-1797.\n8. Delayed diagnosis and subsequent treatment delay can lead to a permanently discontinuous or lengthened tendon; patients experience poorer functional performance and strength. Additionally, surgical repair is more complicated with a higher risk of complications. \n\nAccurate identification and referral can prevent significant functional morbidity. To facilitate diagnosis, point of care ultrasound (POCUS) is a helpful adjunctive tool to confirm the suspected diagnosis.  Ultrasound has been found to be 79%-100% sensitive for this injury. Evaluate the AT systematically in two planes: a superior-inferior direction (longitudinal) and medial-lateral (axial) through the full length and width of the tendon through the myotendinous junction.  In a healthy tendon, the fibers are oriented in a fibrillar linear and regular pattern.  In the disrupted tendon, the fibers may appear thickened, wavy, or as an abrupt edge of a completely disrupted tendon stump with/without retraction.  Secondary signs of AT tear include hypoechogenic areas within or deep to the tendon. A common pitfall in the evaluation of a tendon is to mistake anisotropy for AT tearing or rupture.  Anisotropy is the natural tendency for a structure to have apparent changing density as the angle of sound waves directed at the tissue changes.  The tendon will appear to change from a hyperechoic to hypoechoic structure as the ultrasound transducer is fanned. This can lead to the common pitfall that a hypoechoic structure appears torn.  Fanning and toeing the probe to evaluate for anisotropy and looking for secondary signs of rupture can help distinguish between a ruptured tendon and a normal healthy tendon. Additionally, gentle dynamic active or passive movement placing the tendon under slight tension can help distinguish the presence of tear or rupture.  A subtle tear can be exaggerated with gentle dorsiflexion of the foot as the tendon is stretched to length. If a full thickness tear is present, the distal stump will move across the screen as seen in the associated video.  \n\nThe patient was diagnosed with a full thickness AT rupture. The patient's foot was braced in an equine position, and the patient was given close outpatient orthopedic follow-up.  Surgical therapy was selected and the patient is recovering well.\n\nReferences: \n1. Hartgerink P, Fessell D, Jacobson J, van Holsbeeck M. Full- versus partial-thickness achilles tendon tears: sonographic accurancy and characterization in 26 cases with surgical correlation. Radiology. 2001;220(2):406-412.\n2. Steginsky BD, Van Dyke B, Berlet GC. The missed achilles tear: now what? Foot Ankle Clin. 2017;22(4):715-734. doi: 10.1016/j.fcl.2017.07.004.\n3. Singh D. Acute Achilles tendon rupture. BMJ. 2015;351:h4722. doi: 10.1136/bmj.h4722.\n4. Robinson P. Sonography of common tendon injuries.  Am J Roentgenol. 2009;193(3):607-618. doi: 10.2214/AJR.09.2808.\n5. Ultrasonographic Findings of Acute Achilles Tendon Rupture. JETem 2019. 4(4):V14-16. https://doi.org/10.21980/J8063S\n\nHistory of present illness:  \nA 47-year-old male presents with acute right Achilles tendon (AT) pain.  When he was vaulting off a diving board, he felt a snapping sensation in his right lower extremity, with a sudden onset pain and associated swelling.\n\nSignificant findings: \nThe ultrasound video clip shows a longitudinal view of the AT during a dynamic exam. \nWhile the patient\u2019s foot is gently passively dorsi/plantar flexed, the video demonstrates first a normal Achilles tendon (from the unaffected extremity) without disruption (highlighted by a yellow bracket on screen left).  Then it shows an abnormal tendon (the patient\u2019s affected side) with disruption of the typical linear tendon fibers (red arrow identifies area of rupture). Dynamic testing shows the movement of the distal stump of the AT is evident adjacent to hypoechoic fluid that is reactive edema or blood from the acute rupture.  \n\nDiscussion: \nAchilles tendon rupture identified in the emergency department is often made by history and physical exam alone; however, up to 20% of ruptures are missed during the hyperacute phase.    Delayed diagnosis and subsequent treatment delay can lead to a permanently discontinuous or lengthened tendon; patients experience poorer functional performance and strength. Additionally, surgical repair is more complicated with a higher risk of complications. \n\nAccurate identification and referral can prevent significant functional morbidity. To facilitate diagnosis, point of care ultrasound (POCUS) is a helpful adjunctive tool to confirm the suspected diagnosis.  Ultrasound has been found to be 79%-100% sensitive for this injury. Evaluate the AT systematically in two planes: a superior-inferior direction (longitudinal) and medial-lateral (axial) through the full length and width of the tendon through the myotendinous junction.  In a healthy tendon, the fibers are oriented in a fibrillar linear and regular pattern.  In the disrupted tendon, the fibers may appear thickened, wavy, or as an abrupt edge of a completely disrupted tendon stump with/without retraction.  Secondary signs of AT tear include hypoechogenic areas within or deep to the tendon. A common pitfall in the evaluation of a tendon is to mistake anisotropy for AT tearing or rupture.  Anisotropy is the natural tendency for a structure to have apparent changing density as the angle of sound waves directed at the tissue changes.  The tendon will appear to change from a hyperechoic to hypoechoic structure as the ultrasound transducer is fanned. This can lead to the common pitfall that a hypoechoic structure appears torn.  Fanning and toeing the probe to evaluate for anisotropy and looking for secondary signs of rupture can help distinguish between a ruptured tendon and a normal healthy tendon. Additionally, gentle dynamic active or passive movement placing the tendon under slight tension can help distinguish the presence of tear or rupture.  A subtle tear can be exaggerated with gentle dorsiflexion of the foot as the tendon is stretched to length. If a full thickness tear is present, the distal stump will move across the screen as seen in the associated video.  \n\nThe patient was diagnosed with a full thickness AT rupture. Estos dos t\u00e9rminos se encuentran relacionados por el uso de las tecnolog\u00edas u herramientas que necesitan para ser usados entre los cuales podemos mencionar joystick, teclados, rat\u00f3n, videoc\u00e1mara, aud\u00edfonos, micr\u00f3fonos, monitor, gafas, drones, superficies de proyecci\u00f3n1,2.\nPor otra parte, seg\u00fan Rebollo (2018), la prevenci\u00f3n de riesgos laborales es conocida como el desarrollo y aplicaci\u00f3n de las medidas necesarias para evitar, o en su defecto minimizar, los riesgos en el trabajo; el sector de la construcci\u00f3n para el  a\u00f1o 2015 tiene el mayor \u00edndice de siniestralidad (6794, seg\u00fan cita este autor a partir del Informe Anual de Accidentes de Trabajo en Espa\u00f1a)5.\nEs por ello, que considero pertinente dirigir el presente v\u00eddeo a los T\u00e9cnicos de Prevenci\u00f3n Laboral y al personal sanitario del \u00e1rea de Medicina del Trabajo, con el fin de introducirles en el mundo de las tecnolog\u00edas inform\u00e1ticas que permiten abordar de forma innovadora la preparaci\u00f3n de los trabajadores de la construcci\u00f3n para disminuir las cifras de siniestralidad3,5; ya que, si bien existe una normativa bien fundamentada, donde indica la obligatoriedad de dicha formaci\u00f3n, las estad\u00edsticas indican que las acciones a\u00fan no han sido suficiente, en consecuencia, implantar este tipo de tecnolog\u00edas nos permitir\u00edan llevar al trabajador a un plano m\u00e1s real de los riesgos y usar esas ventajas vanguardistas para detectar los riesgos en un contexto real y aplicar los correctivos necesarios, incluyendo conceptos de gamificaci\u00f3n, como lo explican en un v\u00eddeo del canal de Ludoprevenci\u00f3n6 sobre una tarjeta con puntos para detectar conductas de riesgo laboral. \n\nFuentes consultadas: \n1. Il y a trois formes d'autophagie\u00a0: la macro autophagie, la micro autophagie et l'autophagie m\u00e9diat\u00e9e par les prot\u00e9ines chaperons. \n\nL'autophagie est d\u00e9clench\u00e9e par\u00a0:\n- Augmentation AMPK AMP \"activated protein kinase\", qui est une\u00a0enzyme\u00a0intervenant dans le m\u00e9tabolisme \u00e9nerg\u00e9tique\n- Diminution de l'insuline \n- Diminution de MTor cible de la\u00a0rapamycine\u00a0chez les mammif\u00e8res, qui est une\u00a0enzyme\u00a0de la famille des\u00a0s\u00e9rine/thr\u00e9onine kinases\u00a0qui r\u00e9gule la\u00a0prolif\u00e9ration cellulaire, la\u00a0croissance cellulaire, la\u00a0mobilit\u00e9 cellulaire, la\u00a0survie cellulaire.\n\nC\u00e9tose\u00a0: \u00e9tat dans lequel on retrouve de nombreux corps c\u00e9toniques dans le sang. Les corps c\u00e9toniques servent de substrat \u00e9nerg\u00e9tique quand les r\u00e9serves de sucre sont \u00e9puis\u00e9es et sont produits par la d\u00e9gradation des lipides au niveau du foie. On assiste a une baisse de l'insuline, de mTor et augmentation de AMPK dans la mesure ou la r\u00e9ponse insulin\u00e9mique est plus faible avec les graisses que le sucre.\n\nC\u00e9tose et autophagie ne sont pas \u00e9quivalents mais il y a quand m\u00eame des corr\u00e9lations. Lorsque l'on je\u00fbne, d\u00e8s que les r\u00e9serves de sucre et glycog\u00e8ne sont \u00e9puis\u00e9es alors on passe en c\u00e9tose. Ces corps c\u00e9toniques en circulation favorisent \u00e9norm\u00e9ment de processus de d\u00e9toxification du corps.\n\nEn c\u00e9tose le niveau d'insuline et de mTor sont diminu\u00e9s, cela favorise l'autophagie. \n- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29056525\n- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15883160\n\nAlors quoi manger\u00a0avant le je\u00fbne ? \u00c7a d\u00e9pend. Avant le je\u00fbne l'id\u00e9al est de favoriser une baisse des niveaux d'insuline qui va faire en sorte que l'on passera plus rapidement en autophagie, favoriser la c\u00e9tose en diminuant fortement les sucres dans les deux ou trois jours pr\u00e9c\u00e9dents. Et quoi consommer apr\u00e8s le je\u00fbne\u00a0? Tout d\u00e9pend de votre but. Pour sortir plus vite de l'\u00e9tat de je\u00fbne alors il est pr\u00e9f\u00e9rable de consommer du sucre pour faire remonter les niveaux d'insuline. Pour maintenir un max de temps l'autophagie et la lipolyse alors un r\u00e9gime pauvre en sucre et riche en graisses pour diminuer la r\u00e9ponse insulin\u00e9mique.\n\n________________\n\nJ'ai Coherent policy development requires strategic, logical assessment of interlinkages, trade-offs and opportunities within and across sectors and over spatial and temporal scales. However, for many countries realising policy coherence is challenging. \n\nIn this webinar, we shared new analysis of differing degrees of policy coherence to achieve sustainable development in the water, energy and food (agriculture) sectors, including meeting the Paris Agreement on climate change and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). \n\nFindings and recommendations were illustrated with case studies of policy coherence for Tanzania, and Malawi, and local experience from Zambia in addressing this challenge.\n\nSpeakers:\n\nProf. Andy Dougill (University of Leeds)\nIntroductions to the topic\nSkip to Andy's presentation 10:02\n\nDr Joanna Pardoe (LSE Grantham Research Institute)\nLessons from Policy and Practice in Tanzania\nSkip to Joanna's presentation 17:24\n\nMr Martin Sishekanu (Dialogue International, Zambia)\nThe role of the ICCS/NCCS in policy coherence in Zambia\nSkip to Martin's presentation 26:07\n\nThe webinar presentation as well as the list of Q&A's are available for download on the Future Climate for Africa website: https://goo.gl/vxv3eS", "publishedAt": "2018-10-09T10:45:21Z", "title": "Webinar: Policy Coherence for Sustainable Development", "channelId": "UC0-qGXRnIHH4O8gqeS0lwUA", "channelTitle": "Future Climate For Africa"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H4M39S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "195", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "xze4X1lZbKw"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.009"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.013", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "AuIII complex with a thiosemicarbazone - potential drug for Chagas disease", "channelId": "UCrU3IhE2fIFR7IRhKD7tKKA", "defaultLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "Ronaldo J. In order to get a preliminary insight into the mechanism of action of these compounds, in vitro experiments of fluorescence quenching and enzymatic activity were per- formed using the AuIII complex and Trypanosoma cruzi Old Yellow Enzyme (TcOYE) which indicated that the gold derivative was capable of abstracting the hydride from the prosthetic FMN group of the enzyme. Additionally, molecular docking studies followed by semiempirical simulations showed that the [AuCl(L1)] binds to the binary complex TcOYE/FMN, almost parallel to the FMN prosthetic group, in a close distance that an electron/proton transfer might occur among them. \n\nFrom the article:\n\nPtII, PdII and AuIII complexes with a thiosemicarbazone derived from diacethylmonooxime: Structural analysis, trypanocidal activity, cytotoxicity and first insight into the antiparasitic mechanism of action\nAna C.R. The LTASS technique includes the recording of a long speech sample and analysis of frequency and intensity distributions of that recorded speech sample. This method offers an acoustic representation of the language in daily conservations and helps to obtain additional information on spectral energy distribution of a speech signal in a longer speech sample.\r\nKey Words:\r\nLong-term average spectra, Post lingual, Cochlear implant, Voice analysis, Auditory feedback loop\n\r\n\r- video upload powered by https://www.TunesToTube.com", "tags": ["Postlingual", "Cochlear", "Implant", "Users", "Long-term", "average", "speech", "spectra", "(LTASS)"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT56S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "175", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "dqz7s_kigRE"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.013"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.014", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "what Happens to our Eyes when we watch YouTube in Bed | Explained in Tamil", "channelId": "UCi1IORZCRWSEL0tKypwQYgw", "channelTitle": "Curiosity Tamil", "publishedAt": "2020-07-15T06:55:38Z", "description": "What will Happens to our Eyes When we Watch YouTube videos or anything using a smart phone, laptop or any other screen in Bed?\nCheck out this video Explained in Tamil to find out?\n\n\nIpo neenga Intha video unga cellphone moolama bed la padututu pathitu irupinga. Sfakianakis,Anapafseos 5 Agios Nikolaos 72100 Crete Greece,00302841026182,00306932607174,alsfakia@gmail.com,\r\nhttps://plus.google.com/communities/115462130054650919641?sqinv=VFJWaER0c2NCRl9ERzRjZWhxQmhzY09kVV84cjRn\r\n,\r\n,https://plus.google.com/u/0/+AlexandrosGSfakianakis\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA\r\n,\r\nhttps://twitter.com/g_orl?lang=el,\r\nhttps://www.instagram.com/alexandrossfakianakis/,\r\n\r\n\r\nArticle in Press\r\nTreatment Outcomes of Bilateral Medialization Thyroplasty for Presbylaryngis\r\nJordan J. Allensworth1,'Correspondence information about the author Jordan J. AllensworthEmail the author Jordan J. Allensworth, Karla O'Dell, Aaron Ziegler, Linda Bryans, Paul Flint, Joshua Schindler\r\nDOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jvoice.2017.10.014\r\nhideArticle Info\r\nPublication History\r\nPublished online: January 08, 2018\r\nAccepted: October 18, 2017\r\nAbstract\r\nFull Text\r\nImages\r\nReferences\r\nSummary\r\nBackground\r\nPresbylaryngis is a common cause of dysphonia in elderly patients. Type I thyroplasty serves to improve glottic closure and vocal quality by correcting bowing. Although unilateral and injection-based procedures are well-characterized in the treatment of broadly defined glottic insufficiency, there are insufficient outcomes data for bilateral medialization thyroplasty in the treatment of presbylaryngis. The aim of this study was to review the change in measures of vocal quality before and after bilateral medialization thyroplasty for presbylaryngis.\r\n\r\nStudy Design\r\nThis is a retrospective case series.\r\n\r\nMethods\r\nThe records of 21 patients with presbylaryngis undergoing bilateral medialization thyroplasty between 2007 and 2014 were reviewed. Implant materials included silastic (n\u2009=\u200917) and hydroxyapatite (n\u2009=\u20094). Preoperative and postoperative comparison of vocal function was conducted using Voice Handicap Index, maximum phonation time, auditory-perceptual severity ratings, and blinded paired-comparison of Consensus Auditory-Perceptual Evaluation of Voice and Visual-perceptual stroboscopic ratings. Paired sample t tests were used to assess all outcome measures.\r\n\r\nResults\r\nSignificant improvements were found in Voice Handicap Index scores (P\u2009\u20090.007), maximum phonation time (P\u2009\u20090.03), Consensus Auditory-Perceptual Evaluation of Voice (P\u2009\u20090.04), and clinician rating of vocal quality (P\u2009\u20090.0001). Blinded raters noted a significant improvement in audio (P\u2009\u20090.05) and videostroboscopic (P\u2009\u20090.003) samples after surgery. There were no operative complications observed, and median hospital stay was one night.\r\n\r\nConclusions\r\nPatients with presbylaryngis demonstrated significant improvement in both objective and subjective measures of vocal quality following bilateral medialization thyroplasty. These data suggest that medialization thyroplasty is a safe option that warrants consideration in the treatment of presbylaryngis.\r\n\r\nKey Words:\r\nPresbylaryngis, Atrophy, Medialization, Thyroplasty, Bilateral\n\r\n\r- video upload powered by https://www.TunesToTube.com", "tags": ["Bilateral", "Medialization", "Thyroplasty", "for", "Presbylaryngis"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M51S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "190", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "G6-COQvVUG8"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.014"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.015", "items": [{"snippet": {"description": "", "publishedAt": "2018-11-27T08:41:19Z", "title": "BRE470 Focused study TUT003 Group1", "channelId": "UCiTPyAKBYYFMUGMW-9DWyuA", "channelTitle": "yuhung chen"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT9M38S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "23", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "JMRve79Z9Sg"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.015"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.015", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Top Foods to avoid during Pregnancy. \u0917\u0930\u094d\u092d\u093e\u0935\u0938\u094d\u0925\u093e \u092e\u0947\u0902 \u0905\u092f\u094b\u0917\u094d\u092f \u0906\u0939\u093e\u0930.", "channelId": "UC0h2aM46SOcElguudp7Fcow", "channelTitle": "Ayurved for You", "publishedAt": "2018-10-17T07:03:48Z", "description": "Shifayu Ayurved presents an awareness video for pregnant women \"Top Foods to avoid during Pregnancy. \u0917\u0930\u094d\u092d\u093e\u0935\u0938\u094d\u0925\u093e \u092e\u0947\u0902 \u0905\u092f\u094b\u0917\u094d\u092f \u0906\u0939\u093e\u0930. \" \n          \n                Foods play important role for our healthy body system.\nWrong foods have their own adverse effects. You could not see through it at all and seemed like an overcast day either right before or shortly after a storm.\n\n**I don't know how true this following statement is but someones research said that this was whale sperm churned up.\n\nDNA repair\nCyanobacteria are challenged by environmental stresses and internally generated reactive oxygen species that cause DNA damage. Cyanobacteria possess numerous E. coli-like DNA repair genes.[78] Several DNA repair genes are highly conserved in cyanobacteria, even in small genomes, suggesting that core DNA repair processes such as recombinational repair, nucleotide excision repair and methyl-directed DNA mismatch repair are common among cyanobacteria.[78] Cassier-Chauvat C, Veaudor T, Chauvat F (2016). \"Comparative Genomics of DNA Recombination and Repair in Cyanobacteria: Biotechnological Implications\". Front Microbiol. 7: 1809. doi:10.3389/fmicb.2016.01809. PMC 5101192. PMID 27881980\n\nNatural genetic transformation\nCyanobacteria are capable of natural genetic transformation.[79][80][81] Natural genetic transformation is the genetic alteration of a cell resulting from the direct uptake and incorporation of exogenous DNA from its surroundings. For bacterial transformation to take place, the recipient bacteria must be in a state of competence, which may occur in nature as a response to conditions such as starvation, high cell density or exposure to DNA damaging agents. In chromosomal transformation, homologous transforming DNA can be integrated into the recipient genome by homologous recombination, and this process appears to be an adaptation for repairing DNA damage.\nBernstein H, Bernstein C, Michod RE (January 2018). \"Sex in microbial pathogens\". Infect. Genet. Evol. 57: 8\u201325. doi:10.1016/j.meegid.2017.10.024. PMID 29111273\n\nRecent research has suggested the potential application of cyanobacteria to the generation of renewable energy by directly converting sunlight into electricity. Internal photosynthetic pathways can be coupled to chemical mediators that transfer electrons to external electrodes. In the shorter term, efforts are underway to commercialize algae-based fuels such as diesel, gasoline, and jet fuel.\nCyanobacteria may possess the ability to produce substances that could one day serve as anti-inflammatory agents and combat bacterial infections in humans.Researchers from several space agencies argue that cyanobacteria could be used for producing goods for human consumption in future manned outposts on Mars, by transforming materials available on this planet.\n\nHealth Benefits-Edible blue-green algae reduce the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines by inhibiting NF-\u03baB pathway in macrophages and splenocytes.[119] Sulfate polysaccharides exhibit immunomodulatory, antitumor, antithrombotic, anticoagulant, anti-mutagenic, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and even antiviral activity against HIV, herpes, and hepatitis.[120] ***(SIDE NOTE) Wonder if this is a drug being explored for CORONAVIRUS CURE?", "publishedAt": "2020-04-30T11:20:44Z", "title": "DREAM 4/30/2020", "channelId": "UCP0Un6Aa7EnPwgqRN1Hh1Vw", "channelTitle": "Jesus1stalways"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M6S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "26", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "3"}, "id": "RxN4zKcu25I"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.024"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.10.024", "items": [{"snippet": {"description": "In which I go through the basics of Insulin Resistance.\n\n\n\nWebsite references:\n\nhttps://www.ecirhorse.org/\n\nhttps://www.gravelproofhoof.org/magnesium\n\nJournal Article or Book References:\n\nAsplin, K. Then the coverslip is placed on a slide with the sealing vaseline border to prevent the preparation from drying out too quickly. The preparation is then placed on the microscope with the coverslip up. Observation starts immediately.\n\nContact: Dr. Alexander Kudryavtsev, St-Petersburg State University (alexander.kudryavtsev@spbu.ru)", "tags": ["Amoebozoa", "Discosea", "Vannellida", "Ripella", "Ripella tribonemae", "freshwater amoeba", "differential interference contrast", "light microscopy"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M4S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "46", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "_OcQ0t9Xt3k"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2017.09.003"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.media.2017.10.002", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "A Multiscale Model of Erosive Wear", "channelId": "UCvuBSeOFPXpA2nG1TGzsTsQ", "channelTitle": "lequi7", "publishedAt": "2019-10-07T13:34:41Z", "description": "Short presentation of a multiscale numerical model to simulate the process of erosion due to particle impacts. \n\nFor more information:\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.wear.2017.10.002\nhttps://doi.org/10.3390/ijtpp4020009\nhttps://doi.org/10.1088/1755-1315/240/7/072014\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.wear.2019.04.023", "tags": ["multiscale model", "multiscale", "simulation", "cfd", "erosion", "erosive wear", "hydroabrasive erosion", "computational fluid dynamics", "computational solid mechanics", "particle impact", "numerical simulation"]}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M1S"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "3", "dislikeCount": "0", "viewCount": "136", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "6KcQIhGOrJQ"}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2017.10.002"}, {"q": "10.1016/j.media.2017.10.002", "items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Easy Lollipop chicken| Great for Parties| How To", "channelId": "UCtgb7hRjyz0BGDZfMe-IFng", "channelTitle": "House of Helwa", "publishedAt": "2020-05-18T10:12:03Z", "description": "Hi Hunnies,\n\nThank you for tuning in to my second video! Instead, terms and concepts are used that are familiar to Westerners. The explanations rely on the intelligent tissue theory, which is a new explanation for acupuncture, developed over many years by an experienced Chinese Medicine acupuncturist (myself) who is also trained in a range of sciences.\n\nFOR FURTHER INFORMATION\nThe following is an inexpensive book that is aimed at the general reader and gives a good overview of acupuncture, what it can treat and how it works:\nhttp://www.curiouspages.com/ae\nSee also, my Amazon pages:\nhttps://www.amazon.com/Fletcher-Kovich/e/B01GHOPYEY/\nOr:\nhttps://www.amazon.co.uk/Fletcher-Kovich/e/B01GHOPYEY/ \n\nTHE CONFUSION BETWEEN THE PANCREAS AND SPLEEN IN CHINESE MEDICINE\nThe earliest surviving scripts that record the main Chinese Medicine knowledge, date back to around 200 BC. At that time, the internal organs had been identified and named. However, the spleen was mistakenly thought to be the major digestive organ, associated with the stomach, while the pancreas was overlooked. But in fact, it is the pancreas that serves this function, and the spleen plays no part in digestion. Unfortunately, this mistake has been perpetuated to today, and in Chinese Medicine, whenever the pancreas is referred to, it is known as the spleen. Hopefully, this mistake will soon be corrected in textbooks, and in Chinese Medicine clinics. For a fuller discussion, see pages 61-63 in the following book:\nhttp://www.curiouspages.com/atac/\n\nThe \u201cresonance\u201d between an organ and its meridian locations, is explained by the intelligent tissue theory. The explanations rely on the intelligent tissue theory, which is a new explanation for acupuncture, developed over many years by an experienced Chinese Medicine acupuncturist (myself) who is also trained in a range of sciences.\n\nFOR FURTHER INFORMATION\nThe following is an inexpensive book that is aimed at the general reader and gives a good overview of acupuncture, what it can treat and how it works:\nhttp://www.curiouspages.com/ae\nSee also, my Amazon pages:\nhttps://www.amazon.com/Fletcher-Kovich/e/B01GHOPYEY/\nOr:\nhttps://www.amazon.co.uk/Fletcher-Kovich/e/B01GHOPYEY/\n\nThe \u201cresonance\u201d between an organ and its meridian locations, is explained by the intelligent tissue theory. In another video I will explain how this term came about, and how it relates to the intelligent tissue theory.\n\nWHAT ARE THE \u201cMERIDIANS\u201d?\nFor more information on this, please see the following:\nhttps://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2005290118300037\nAnd Chapters 17 and 19 in the following book:\nhttp://www.curiouspages.com/atac/\n\nTHE CONFUSION BETWEEN THE PANCREAS AND SPLEEN IN CHINESE MEDICINE\nThe earliest surviving scripts that record the main Chinese Medicine knowledge, date back to around 200 BC. At that time, the internal organs had been identified and named. However, the spleen was mistakenly thought to be the major digestive organ, associated with the stomach, while the pancreas was overlooked. But in fact, it is the pancreas that serves this function, and the spleen plays no part in digestion. Unfortunately, this mistake has been perpetuated to today, and in Chinese Medicine, whenever the pancreas is referred to, it is known as the spleen. Hopefully, this mistake will soon be corrected in textbooks, and in Chinese Medicine clinics. For a fuller discussion, see pages 61-63 in the following book:\nhttp://www.curiouspages.com/atac/\n\nFor further information on the Chinese Medicine pulses and how they are produced, please see Chapter 15, pages 299-305, in the following book:\nhttp://www.curiouspages.com/atac/\n\nMY PUBLISHED PAPERS ON ACUPUNCTURE AND THE INTELLIGENT TISSUE THEORY, WHICH CAN ALL BE READ IN FULL, FREE OF CHARGE:\nKovich F.
